If I'm not capture by the first page then the author has lost me.. I have never read or heard of Francine Rivers before, in fact read this book after reading Masterpiece and saw the comparison review to 'Redeeming Love'. While Masterpiece was good, I can understand why readers fell in love with Redeeming love. It's a beautiful love story with themes running through it from the Book of Hosea in the Bible. I confess, halfway i would have given it a 4.5 if I'm honest. There were times when it didn't show very well when Sarah's mother became a prostitute, it seems like after her lover and then herb parents rejected her she just ended up in prostitution. After being so descriptive with the character 's thoughts the author appears to jump from being a rejected mistress and daughter then at the docks with Sarah selling her body to keep them. However, the story picks back up momentum and is captivating how Sarah becomes Angel and is sold into prostitution and inherits her mother's brokenness and enters what appears to be a unbreakable cycle of learned behaviour of the soul. Then in the background and coming to the forefront of Angel's life is Michael Hosea. He falls in love with Angel right in the middle of her broken mess of life. I'm glad he wasn't a Mr Perfect in all his ways and that he was challenged by his own weaknesses and pride. His heartbreak when she keeps running away back to the only thing she knew and her betrayal. He keeps going after her and 'choosing ' to forgive her each time until the penny drops and he realises he has to give her up and let her choose him. I would recommend this book to beloved of non believer. True love is not shallow, it runs deep. It hurts and it cannot be destroyed. The theme of God's unconditional love is moving and humbling. The author capture d Angel 's self hate and if course hating and wanting nothing to do with God.Finally. I would be interested to see this out on a big screen but it would need a cast who could be true to its authenticity and not spare blushes. E.g. Like Passion of the Christ is probably the most authentic portrayal I've seen to what was true of that time.A beautiful and powerful message of real love 'no strings attached '.

I had just finished Francine Rivers the masterpiece and wanted to read another of her books, this was amazing! Set in the days of little house on the prairie, and after a tough beginning reading about Angels awful start in life (which at times was very uncomfortable to read), the book takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions as you learn about a God‚Äôs relentless search for us and His love. At times I wanted to cry for Angel and Michael as they went through their trials and scream ‚Äòwhat are you doing!‚Äô and towards the end I couldn‚Äôt put the book down as I wanted to see what would happen next. It is such a powerful picture of our walk with God and how He perseveres until we begin to fully trust Him and accept His love. A must read for Christians and non Christians alike.

Bought this book after a recommendation on Facebook. So impressed I bought three more for friends. I loved it and tried to stay awake at night reading it. I just felt the love of God/Jesus pouring out as I red the words. Have kept it at the side of my bed ready to read again.

This book is about the unconditional love of God , HIS grace and mercy . How HE keeps drawing us to HIMSELF in a gentle way . HE brings us to HIS knowledge through love not by force. Amazing ! Awesome God is HE.Every Christian needs to read this book and we should ask God to teach us how to love like HIM and how to live a life preaching Christ not just in words.Thank you for the book Francine Rivers.Indeed how great the father loves us.

I rate this book a 5 out of 5 for reasons beyond the fact that is a very good novel. The title of my rating 'A Book for Your Life' was chosen because it is loosely modelled on the story of Hosea in the bible, but more so because it is directly modelled after the love that Christ has for us. I have read this book more than 10 times and every time I am forced to reflect on my life. Get this and know what true love is, and a good read as well!

ive read thousands of books- this isnt a joke, im a bookworm and have been reading hundreds of books a year since i first learned to read- and i have to say ive never read such an amazing book.I hate christian fiction, so i wasnt sure about reading this book but i liked the sound of the story line so after seeing it at my local library, decided to give it a go, and im so glad i did, i love this book, so much so in fact i ended up buying it!It has a sad beginning but once you get past that its a beautiful story about:California‚Äôs gold country, 1850. A time when men sold their souls for a bag of gold and women sold their bodies for a place to sleep.Angel expects nothing from men but betrayal. Sold into prostitution as a child, she survives by keeping her hatred alive. And what she hates most are the men who use her, leaving her empty and dead inside.Then she meets Michael Hosea, a man who seeks his Father‚Äôs heart in everything. Michael obeys God‚Äôs call to marry Angel and to love her unconditionally. Slowly, day by day, he defies Angel‚Äôs every bitter expectation, until despite her resistance, her frozen heart begins to thaw.But with her unexpected softening comes overwhelming feelings of unworthiness and fear. And so Angel runs. Back to the darkness, away from her husband‚Äôs pursuing love, terrified of the truth she no longer can deny: Her final healing must come from the One who loves her even more than Michael does‚Ä¶the One who will never let her go.Read it, i seriously doubt you ll ever find a more moving story. I highly recommend this book and give it 5 out of 5 stars.

I read somewhere that this book has been totted as being as good as Paullina Simons' The Bronze Horseman, it isn't, but it is a very worthy read even for someone like me that doesn't like to have 'God' rammed down their throats every minute.....Skilled characterization, fantastic plot development, good use of dramatic cadence, all in all a novel written by a writer who actually thought and cared about all these things.It took some time to read, mainly because this is the paperback version and I'm just no longer used to lagging a book around with me and so it was read in fits and starts but in the end I just put my head down and refused to stop until it was over. And I'll glad I made the effort.

It took me a while to follow up one of my best friend's recommendations - I borrowed her book and have since bought my own, shared it with members of my youth group and bought it as presents for many of my friends and family.Based on the story of Hosea from the Old Testament, it is the story of Gods love for his people who constantly turn away from him and try to distance themselves from his love - and yet he pursues them with a forgiving and compassionate love that knows no bounds despite the pain it causes him. It is all told through the love story between a very damaged young girl and a man who knows God and is given God's heart for this woman and shows her how to be loved and how to be free.This was the first time that I truly understood the book of Hosea and now read it in a whole new light. It has also shown me the outworking of unconditional love and its bitter sweet nature.Folk could appreciate this book on a number of different levels:1. A very well written love story that will keep you gripped to the end and wring your heart.2. A book that can be used as part of a marriage preparation course once the basics have been covered.2. A book for those asking questions about the nature of God's love for his people.3. A book for those who have been badly hurt by others and feel dirty or unworthy - a path towards understanding and God's healing.4. It also looks at human judgements, hypocrisy, forgiveness....I have now bought many others of Francine's books and find that they all have the same truth, power and page-turning grip, each one looking at different aspects of God's word and with massive messages for us all.

Este libro revela una comprensi√≥n importante que rodea los acontecimientos del 11-S y tambi√©n el colapso de la industria financiera en 2008. Tenga en cuenta que su foco central est√° en Am√©rica, pero lo que sucede con Am√©rica impactar√° lo que sucede a nivel mundial. Los √∫ltimos ocho a√±os de liderazgo ineficaces han surgido muchos problemas a nivel internacional, desde el extremismo religioso a una recuperaci√≥n econ√≥mica sin brillo.Si todav√≠a no ha comprado el libro, no lo haga. El material en The Harbinger se establece en un formato de historia, que es sobre todo el di√°logo y puede ser repetitivo (lo que sucede cuando se habla con alguien con un regalo de ense√±anza). Leer el libro es como leer a dos personas enviando mensajes de texto entre s√≠. Puede obtener toda la informaci√≥n del libro simplemente obteniendo el video del autor: El Juicio de Isa√≠as 9:10, as√≠ como obtener La Gu√≠a de Estudio del Harbinger: Decodificar los Misterios y Responder a la Llamada que Puede Cambiar el Futuro de Am√©rica - Y la Suya, sin La historia y el pelusa que viene junto con el Harbinger.Tambi√©n es importante mencionar que la gu√≠a de estudio tambi√©n tiene informaci√≥n que no se encuentra en el libro o el video. La informaci√≥n suplementaria en la gu√≠a de estudio tiene detalles sobre el desarrollo de la historia y un poco sobre c√≥mo se produjo el libro.Por lo que me han dicho (por un amigo m√≠o que en realidad asiste a la iglesia del autor), el pastor Jonathan Cahn cree que lo que sucedi√≥ con el antiguo Israel tambi√©n ocurrir√° en Am√©rica. Despu√©s del reinado del rey Salom√≥n, el reino se dividi√≥ en dos. Con dos reinos, surgieron dos reyes diferentes, liderando dos naciones. Del mismo modo, hay dos mentalidades muy diferentes en Am√©rica, una puesta en la celebraci√≥n de los valores b√≠blicos, mientras que la otra no. Desde la perspectiva del pastor Jonathan Cahn, aquellas √°reas en Am√©rica que rechazan la direcci√≥n de Dios enfrentar√°n juicio, mientras que aquellos que lo hagan ver√°n Sus bendiciones. Como posible signo de que su perspectiva es verdadera; Recientemente en la ciudad de Nueva York, construyeron el arco al dios pagano Baal, el mismo "dios" mencionado en su libro.Los que est√°n impresionados con su trabajo, debe ir a jim bakker show. Tienen una estrecha relaci√≥n entre s√≠ y han hecho viajes conjuntos junto con sus ministerios. En realidad puede encontrar material del Pastor Jonathan Cahn que no encontrar√° en ninguna otra parte, ni siquiera del propio ministerio del Pastor Jonathan Cahn. Dos recursos adicionales a considerar es el candidato al caos de Dios: Donald J. Trump y el americano Unraveling de Lance Wallnau y In Trump We Trust: E Pluribus Awesome! Por Ann Coulter; Los cuales comprender√°n mejor la situaci√≥n actual de Estados Unidos y confirmar√°n lo que el Pastor Jonathan Cahn habla.

I came to this novel after reading (and being blown away by) The Power. While it may not have the same showstopping hooks, it is a powerful novel in itself - the concept of choosing between embracing rebellion, turning your back on your religion and upbringing OR masquerading as someone else and suppressing your own desires in order to conform is played out through the two female protagonists (Esti and Ronit) as they both struggle to come to terms with the choices they have made. I have no real knowledge of the Orthodox Jewish community in either London or NY (the two main settings) and so came to the novel with an open mind and could not fail to be surprised by the enduring separation of male and female (physically, in the temple, and culturally), and found Alderman‚Äôs presentation of gender issues as compelling as in The Power. The Q&A included at the back of the book was very interesting, and I really recommend this novel both to fans of the author and newcomers. Really gives you something to think about!

Tengo que admitir que le√≠ este libro debido a la pel√≠cula que est√° a punto de estrenarse.El libro era una visi√≥n de la Religi√≥n Ortodoxa Jud√≠a y su cultura, as√≠ que aprend√≠ mucho sobre la fe, la comida, el s√°bado, pero fue exagerado y se volvi√≥ aburrido.Sent√≠ que los personajes eran interesantes pero carec√≠an de profundidad y donde una dimensi√≥n, no me importaban lo suficiente como para tener una preferencia de c√≥mo terminaba y salt√© p√°ginas cerca del final para poder terminarlo. ¬°No hab√≠a escena de sexo! Y s√≠, no estar√≠a fuera de lugar tener uno, ya que era muy relevante y clave para la historia. Los dedos cruzaron la pel√≠cula pasa por alto la escoria y le da un poco de poder emocional - con suerte es mucho mejor que el libro.

A simply wonderful book. Literate and sophisticated and also easy to read and hard to put down, nicely capturing the cloistered world that the writer clearly has some first hand knowledge of as well as looking at that world from the outside.

I saw this book after reading 'The Innocents' by Francesca Segal and after reading the write up and reviews I added it to my Wish List for the future.This is a book written from two perspectives, Robot's and Esti's, two women born into the same Hendon Orthodox Jewish community but one has left and one has stayed. Without giving away anything from the plot there is something that holds them together from their shared pasts.Ronit's father, the Rav has recently died and Ronit is returning from New York to sort out his papers and close up the home. Ronit is successful in her chosen field as a Corporate financial analyst but having just come out of an affair with her married boss, the trip to London, though unwelcome, gives her a little breathing space.The story takes us into the closeted world of her old community, the perceived claustrophobia and the feelings of being watched, judged and found to be lacking. Ronit in her status as an unmarried woman is seen as something of a half person; not fully matured and though it is not mentioned I had the impression she was seen as a disappointment to her late father's memory.This is one of those books where you, the reader is taken into other people's lives and given a snap shot of their circumstances and events and this reminded me of Anne Tyler. Naomi Alderman doesn't write in a dramatic style, even the dramatic moments in this book are played down but that is what I enjoyed about this, she has a way of writing that seemed quite beautiful, especially in her description of the Shabbat preparations.I shall be reading her other books at some point in the future.

This is a beautifully written book immersing the reader into world of North London‚Äôs Orthodox Jewish community. I enjoyed the biblical references, the complexity of Jewish faith and customs, but it was the relatable characters and believable storyline that made this novel shine. I am sad that the book is over 10 years old and I only heard about it due to the upcoming film adaptation. I did say to my other half that living in Hendon will eventually kill us, Naomi writes words to that effect in Disobedience ‚Äì thanks for confirming it for me!

I thought, 4 stars or 5? There were things I liked less, but overall, what I loved more won out... whatI Like d less was maybe the more 'poetic' bits and the migraines... but overall, I loved the book for its portrayal of the Orthodox community with humour but never with any hint of despising, belittling, being too clever - Alderman writes of the community she grew up in with affection. I enjoyed the details of the rituals surrounding death and everyday life, marriage, how you live and what's expected. She describes it as how she left the Orthodox, but she also describes it with the knowledge of an insider, and it is a pleasure to read. It also happens to chime with my novels (on published, one on its way) which describe the inside of Christian fundamentalism with a definite critique but without rancour, and that of course gave me the pleasure of feeling a bit of a younger sister (in terms of literary output)!I'd recommend Disobedience to anyone who enjoys a thoughtful, literary, read, who enjoys learning about the inside of cultures different to their own, who wants to understand where other people are 'coming from', who is interested in the phenomenon of religion/culture and how it can rule your life. It is warm and funny with lots of serious points and some great portraits.

My first Star Wars novel and it was very good too. Imaginative and very easily readable, only took 24 hours to finish.Coming in at about 250 pages, 'Death Troopers' delivers a scary, creepy and fast paced chiller in a clearly recognizable Star Wars environment. Our protagonists occupy a broken down prison barge which encounters a derelict and seemingly abandoned Imperial Star Destroyer drifting in a remote part of the galaxy..... soon all is not what it seems and our heroes (including two Star Wars regulars you may recognise) discover just what the Imperial Biological Weapons Department have created.Needless to say a bloody and frightening experience awaits those who board the Star Destroyer and the ending is a little different to. Don't be put off by the fact that it's ANOTHER zombie yarn, 'Death Troopers' is good and certainly worthy of the Star Wars genre.Well worth the money for a lazy weekends reading.

When I first heard that Lucas Books was going to release a horror novel into the Star Wars universe I was very sceptical. In fact my exact words were 'what the hell are you thinking?'Now I'm not really a fan of horror but I was pleasantly surprised by this book. It was very well written and I found it a real page-turner. The inclusuion of a couple of well-known rougish characters also gave a bit of familiarity to what was a very different setting.Having said that, I found the inclusion of the aforementioned characters a bit forced and I couldn't see how this could have fit in with what they did in the other books that were written about them during this point in the time line.So not a bad read but frankly a book like this has no real place in the Star Wars universe in my humble opinion.

El personaje principal es Fanny Price, el segundo m√°s viejo de una familia pobre y rica. Mientras que Tom, Mar√≠a y Julia nunca los tratan como iguales a ellos, Edmund es muy amable con ella y la trata como desigual. Es tolerada en Mansfield Park, pero no es bienvenida. Aunque a menudo es muy infeliz all√≠ durante su infancia, crece con un fuerte sentido de decencia y virtud y permanece estrechamente conectada con su hermano mayor William, que ha ido a la Marina Real. Con los a√±os, su gratitud por la bondad y bondad de Edmund se convierte en m√°s y m√°s amor.La Sra. Norris, otra hermana de la madre de Fanny, tambi√©n vive en Mansfield. Interfiere con todos los asuntos del hogar en Mansfield Park, mima a los ni√±os Bertram, especialmente a Mar√≠a, a las masas, mientras despreciaba a Fanny y humillaba con palabras. Ella hace la vida dif√≠cil en cada ocasi√≥n para la sobrina sin educaci√≥n en sus ojos. El justo Sir Thomas trata de corregir la influencia perniciosa de su cu√±ada en sus hijos. Sin embargo, falla, y cada vez es m√°s considerado por sus hijas como un patriarca estricto, a quien ocultan sus verdaderos sentimientos y opiniones. A diferencia de su esposa, que tiene poco m√°s intereses que la costura in√∫til y su pug, est√° muy preocupado por la educaci√≥n de los hijos, pero tampoco los trata con amor y, debido a su naturaleza reservada, no tiene acceso a ellos. Las dos hijas superficiales Mar√≠a y Julia se vuelven m√°s vanidosas e imaginativas a lo largo de los a√±os, son muy ego√≠stas y miden su propio valor s√≥lo por su belleza y origen, mientras que Tom se convierte en un le√≥n y jugador de fiesta imprudente y derrochador. S√≥lo Edmund es el √∫nico de los cuatro hermanos que sobrevive a su crianza con un sentido intacto de decencia.La trama real del libro comienza cuando Sir Thomas viaja a Antigua durante dos a√±os despu√©s de enfrentarse a problemas en su plantaci√≥n all√≠. Los enredos emocionales comienzan con la llegada de un hermano, el Sr. y la Srta. Crawford, visitando a su hermana, la Sra. Grant. Ella es la esposa del actual propietario de la parroquia de Mansfield Park. La Srta. Crawford y Edmund se sienten atra√≠dos entre s√≠, aunque Edmund a menudo se preocupa por su falta de modales correctos y puntos de vista irrespetuosos, especialmente por su vocaci√≥n de convertirse en cl√©rigo. El creciente afecto entre los dos aflige a Fanny, que no s√≥lo teme perder a Edmund, sino que tambi√©n siente que su amor por la se√±orita Crawford lo ciega con respecto a sus graves defectos de car√°cter. Mientras tanto, el Sr. Crawford juega con el afecto de ambas hermanas Bertram, a pesar de que Mar√≠a ya est√° comprometida con el poco simple pero muy rico Sr. Rushworth.A la vuelta de Sir Thomas, encuentra a los j√≥venes en medio de los preparativos para una obra de teatro. En ese momento, esta es una ocupaci√≥n extremadamente inapropiada para las j√≥venes de origen aristocr√°tico. S√≥lo que Fanny no particip√≥ en ello. La llegada de Sir Thomas conduce a la cancelaci√≥n del juego, y el Sr. Crawford se va. El matrimonio de Mar√≠a con el Sr. Rushworth tiene lugar a pesar de los celos que ella hab√≠a alimentado sobre su comportamiento con el Sr. Crawford. La joven pareja se va de luna de miel junto con Julia. Durante esta ausencia, Fanny se vuelve m√°s importante para la familia, y su t√≠o muestra m√°s afecto que antes.Cuando el Sr. Crawford regresa a Mansfield Park despu√©s de alg√∫n tiempo de ausencia, Fanny se convierte en el nuevo blanco de sus intentos de coqueteo. Su bondad y bondad, sin embargo, hacen que sus planes fracasen, y √©l se enamora de ellos. Sin embargo, cuando √©l propone su matrimonio, su conocimiento de su anterior comportamiento incorrecto hacia sus primos y su gran afecto por Edmund la llevaron a rechazar su propuesta. Su familia est√° consternada por ello, y Sir Thomas les reprocha por desobediencia e ingratitud. Fanny se mantiene firme, sabiendo que actu√≥ bien. Esto es a√∫n m√°s dif√≠cil para ella porque no puede revelar sus verdaderas razones de rechazo sin exponer a Mar√≠a al mismo tiempo, cosa que Fanny ciertamente no quiere.Sir Thomas planea enviar a Fanny de vuelta a la casa de su familia por unos meses para hacerla consciente de la supuesta necesidad de tener un marido rico. Sr.Crawford viene a visitarla para mostrarle que ha cambiado y que ahora es digno de sus sentimientos. Tambi√©n ayudando a promover la promoci√≥n de su hermano William, esta estrategia logra apaciguar la actitud negativa de Fanny hacia √©l, aunque ella todav√≠a est√° lejos de aceptarlo como marido. Poco despu√©s de irse a Londres, sin embargo, escucha rumores de un esc√°ndalo que le afecta a √©l y a su prima casada Mar√≠a. Resulta m√°s tarde que Crawford reanud√≥ sus coqueteos y peque√±as intrigas debido a la reanudaci√≥n de su conocido en Londres, haciendo que Mar√≠a se quede con √©l. Debido a esto, y debido a la enfermedad de Tom provocada por un viaje anterior, y a la quema de Julia con el Sr. Yates, la situaci√≥n en Mansfield Park es terrible de soportar, y Fanny es llamado de vuelta para ayudar y consolar a su t√≠a y t√≠o durante este tiempo. Como resultado del esc√°ndalo, Edmund se separa de la Srta. Crawford. Despu√©s de alg√∫n tiempo, devolver√° el afecto de Fanny, y los dos se casar√°n.

Era, sin duda, una escritora pendiente, y ha sido un placer leerla.Retrata los personajes con unas pocas palabras y ves c√≥mo aparecen ante ti. Sidney Lumet makes you feel that you are a friend, and he wants to put you in the know about what it's like to make a film. You couldnt ask for a more experienced guide, Lumet is one of the world's greatest directors and he knows all about itThe book is very engagingly written, and conversational in style. It is divided into topics such as 'Actors', and 'Editing', and he takes you through every fascinating aspect of of making a movie from start to finish.Lumet vividly describes his own working day during shooting, and this is sometimes so realistic that you feel as if you are looking over the director's shoulder at significant moments during the job. Lumet knows just how to describe what happens. For example his description of the morning when the actors meet for the first read-through of the script is unforgettable.If you are in any way interested in how a major film gets made, you will probably enjoy this book enormously, it's a classic.

Enjoyed the book from an admired Director. His tales and stories interesting and his method techniques were in some cases similar to tradition but many other enlightening moments and the Hollywood system. Great read for all film-makers.

Good book, but I was surprised to discover coloured highlighter pens had been used extensively on it. There was no mention of that in the description. But it's all still readable, so I'm not complaining. Grumbling a little bit, but not complaining. (I'm English, I can't help myself) Thank you.

One of the best books about films I've read.I'd always loved all the Sidney Lumet films I'd watched, and now I want to watch the rest of them because he gives great examples.Written in a sympathetic and pretty objective manner.
Essential reading for film making students and those interested in the complexity and creative process which exists behind the screenpresentation.
thanks!a
Impressive insight into the art of film making from one of the very best storytellers within the medium.
I find myself analysing movie shots just from reading this book. A great reading for people interested in movie photography

I always found Prospero‚Äôs masque at the end of The Tempest difficult. Back in the late sixties I was too inexperienced to sense how it was a mockery of itself; and studying for ‚ÄúA‚Äù level, it was just not an option, to see the play performed on any stage or in any film. So it was that the masque never lived for me on the page. The peerless Arden could have lightened up. Just over half way through the plot it is real fun to look ‚Äúbehind the scenes‚Äù where Cupid has been trying to get the lovers to indulge in pre-marital intercourse. Cupid has now run off ‚Äúcutting the clouds towards Paphos‚Äù. The light-hearted references to agriculture tie the borderlands of Scotland to Cinque Port marshes of the South. In the way that Penny Lane by The Beatles is wistful, the masque is also fun.I must blame Arden 2 because that masque seemed to be the final straw or ‚Äústover‚Äù. Stover is that female-tennis-player-of-a-word used by Ceres when she is summoning a rainbow to that ‚Äúshort-grassed green‚Äù that Miranda‚Äôs father has prepared with Ariel for his masque to mark the covenants of his daughter and her beloved. ‚ÄúAnd flat meads thatch‚Äôd with stover‚Äù is footnoted in the Arden 3 as ‚Äúmeadows covered with growth of fodder for sheep. Stover is any kind of grass that is stored to make fodder‚Äù. The Arden 2 says ‚Äúwinter food for sheep‚Äù. This is not helpful comment. How can a field be ‚Äúthatched‚Äù? There should be the clarification that only when cut and left to dry may the field be described as ‚Äúthatched‚Äù. Arden might have added perhaps a ‚Äúlong note‚Äù to the fact that even today, in some places, depending on geography, region, climate, and culture, hay is still gathered loose and stacked into stooks without being baled first. ‚ÄúThatched‚Äù means arranged in such a manner that the hay itself "sheds" water when it falls as rain; much as a garden ‚Äúshed‚Äù does.When Iris the rainbow is summoning Ceres, she asks Ceres to leave her wheat and oat crops and the rye and barley. The ‚Äúturfy mountains‚Äù bring to mind the hills of Scotland and The North ‚Äúwhere live nibbling sheep‚Äù. The Arden 3 struggles to shed real light onto the words ‚Äúpioned and twilled brims‚Äù. It admits that this is a ‚Äúlong-debated phrase‚Äù. Anyone familiar today with the lowlands of Romney Marsh will have seen that the reeds all along the drainage dykes are pulled back these days with mechanical diggers. In Shakespeare‚Äôs time the drainage channels also needed to be freed of reeds and obstruction from time to time. This is done in autumn after the reeds and sedges are done. The growth is uprooted and pulled back to clear the channel. In spring this provides good soil for plants to grow. The flowers that grow in spring to garnish that unsightly mud include arrowhead and starry flowers which could in the same way be woven into ‚Äúchaste crowns‚Äù for nymphs (and lovers and children).The Arden 3 is particularly obtuse when it deals with the words that describe a particularly Scottish plant, the broom. Iris beckons Ceres to leave ‚Äúthy broomgroves Whose shadow the dismissed bachelor loves, Being lass-lorn.‚Äù Here is Arden 3: ‚ÄúBroomgroves: areas of terrain covered with yellow-flowered shrubs. Although editors have debated whether broom, which Gerard defines as ‚Äòa bush or shrubbie plant‚Äù‚Äô(Gerard 1130) can be described as growing in a grove, which usually consists of trees (var,201.2) we agree with Orgel that the passage should be taken as Shakespeare‚Äôs invention. Orgel also notes that ‚Äúbroom figures significantly in magic spells designed to ensure the success of love affairs‚Äù, which explains why the dismissed bachelor loves it (Oxf, 174)‚Äù.Child‚Äôs reference work ‚ÄúThe Scottish and English Ballads‚Äù lists a song (#217) that is relevant to the study of The Tempest. You can read the original published pages on Archive.org. The song is called ‚ÄúBroom of the Cowdenknows‚Äù. When Iris, the wife of Juno, materialises, as a rainbow, for Prospero, in the masque played out as the last hurrah of the Magus before he drowns his book, Iris, the messenger from ‚Äúthe queen o‚Äô th‚Äô sky‚Äù calls upon Ceres to leave her crops and cereals and the pastures she calls home. The call to leave in The Tempest is a little difficult to follow at first. The call, simplified reads ‚ÄúCeres, leave your cereal fields, leave your sheep, your hay-stacked fields, leave your dykes whose banks of drawn up reeds and mud will soon, in rainy April, be laced with flowers that nymphs and shepherds will use in much the same way to make ‚Äúchaste crowns‚Äù for themselves. Iris also asks Ceres to leave ‚Äúthy broomgroves Whose shadow the dismissed bachelor loves‚Äù.The Daily Mail late in 2016 reported that ‚ÄúCowdenknowes mansion in Earlston, Berwickshire, a medieval estate that once sheltered Mary Queen of Scots has had ¬£450,000 slashed from its original ¬£2million asking price‚Äù.When I studied this play for the London GCE back in 1969, using the Arden 2 the reference to ‚Äúbroomgroves‚Äù joined the fleet of sinking phrases I tried to keep afloat in my memory for the exam. It was only, years later, in Stratford‚Äôs New Place Garden that I saw the words, as it were, ‚Äúfor the first time‚Äù. The line was taken out of context, engraved on a plate with the words ‚Äú BROOM Cytisus scoparius‚Äù. Why was it, I asked myself, that the groves of broom were loved by the ‚Äúdismiss√®d bachelor‚Äù? Was he moping under the arches of the yellow broom, as I have done myself, as a boy under the bracken or the gorse?Child‚Äôs reference work ‚ÄúThe Scottish and English Ballads‚Äù offers an exhaustive collection of songs that refer to the broom of the Cowdenknows. You can hear Ewan MacColl singing one of them on YouTube.However ‚Ä¶ and I quote from Child:There is an English " ditty " (not a traditional ballad) of a northern lass who got harm while milking her father's ewes, which was printed in the first half of the seventeenth century. It is here given in an appendix.This ditty is "to a pleasant Scotch tune called The broom of Cowden Knowes," and the burden is :With, O the broome, the bonny broome,The broome of Cowden Knowes !Fain would I be in the North Countrey,To milk my dadyes ewes.The tune was remarkably popular, and the burden is found, variously modified, in connection with several songs. Burton, in the fifth edition of his Anatomy of Melancholy, Oxford, 1638, p. 636, says : " The very rusticks and hog-rubbers . . . have their ballads, country tunes, the broome, the bonny, bonny broome," etc. (Chappell). This remark is not found in the fourth edition, Oxford, 1632, p. 544.This song or ‚ÄúEnglish ditty‚Äù was widely known. Burton‚Äôs reference in 1638 seems to be the earliest. The Tempest, if we are to believe the dating ‚Äúexperts‚Äù was written in 1610, the last of Shakespeare‚Äôs plays, written in the reign of the Scottish James 1. Ceres is asked to leave the broomgroves of the Scottish Border country to come down ‚Äúhere on this grass plot‚Äù.It is my contention that this song provides all the explanation necessary. It is a beautiful song, the version of it, sung by a ‚Äúdismissed bachelor‚Äù can be heard by North Sea Gas (and others) on YouTube. He is longing for the Scotch broom that grew in abundance around the castle of Cowdenknowes where in 1566 Mary Queen of Scots famously stayed some years before being beheaded. If James 1 ever saw the play he would have been touched.

I bought the Kindle version of this great play to facilitate reading out loud in a group. But the erratic pagination, with the text suddenly broken by blocks of footnotes, often in the middle of a sentence, made me give up and return gratefully to a properly printed edition - albeit one with a much smaller typeface.It is also extraordinary that the Acts and Scenes are not individually indexed in the table of contents. The whole play has but a single heading! To find your place you have to page through the whole text, or search for a key phrase. To have set this up properly would have meant but an hour or so of editing work. Not to have done so takes away one of the main benefits of an electronic version.Similarly, the footnotes could surely have been better placed all together at the end with live links from the text. The way they are done at the moment is simply infuriating.The impression I am getting is that Kindle editions are sometimes created carelessly by people who have no love of the text or concern about presentation. Or even, extraordinarily, awareness of the potential of the new medium.Frankly, this was a complete waste of the admittedly modest amount of money it cost.

This is an excellent version for children. WE bought it for our grand daughter who is 8. We were taking her to see the new RSC production of the Tempest and wanted her to know the story. She read the whole thing, and was interested in the characters and plot. This is an achievement for the author.

The last, and in my opinion, the greatest of Shakespeare's plays. The story concerns a shipwreck whose survivors land on a mysterious island inhabited by Prospero, the rightful Duke of Milan and his daughter Miranda. There is also a dark, savage, native character named Caliban. During the play Miranda utters the phrase "Oh brave new world that has such people in it", which inspired the title of Aldous Huxley's very popular book "Brave New World". The Tempest has also been drawn upon heavily during both the recent Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies. The attraction of the Arden edition of the play is that apart from the play itself it makes available a wealth of scholarly material relevant to its creation. For that reason I would love to have Arden editions of all of the plays.

This book is huge, it‚Äôs the size and a full sheet of paper. The text is very large, and perfect for somebody who is registered as blind. If you have failing sight then this is the book for you, it makes reading the story far more interesting when you can actually see what the words.

Having long been fascinated by the themes of this play,but no fan of Shakespeare-I decided to buy this CD after studying the cast list and reviews.It is a splendid production,enhanced by the judicious use of music: lute,songs and brass ensemble;and by the sounds of the sea in the background of many scenes.Some famous phrases-some still in common usage-have their origins here :'O brave new world',to name but one.The acting is superb,particularly Sir Ian Mckellen's Prospero and Scott Handy's Ariel.I would recommend to all who,like me,have hitherto given Shakespeare's works a wide berth.

Perhaps not one of Shakespeare's better known plays but it still has immortal lines.I found the language harder than in others of his plays. The extensive foot notes in this Dover Thrift are a boon when reading the play.

Tal como la portada lo dice, el libro nos cuenta brevemente la historia de la humanidad.Nos brinda un an√°lisis de todos los grandes hechos que han tenido lugar en nuestra historia como especie y las implicaciones que han tenido en nuestra forma de pensar, de actuar y de c√≥mo concebimos el mundo.Pasando por acontecimientos como el inicio de la agricultura, la revoluci√≥n cient√≠fica e industrial y la invenci√≥n de ideolog√≠as y conceptos como son las religiones, el imperialismo, el dinero, el capitalismo, etc.El estilo del texto es f√°cil de leer, el autor explica muy bien y la lectura se hace amena, no es pesado y es de un largo medio (450 p√°ginas).Definitivamente un libro que recomiendo mucho para cualquier persona interesada en conocer un poco m√°s sobre la historia de nuestra especie.

El autor te lleva por el libro con un lenguaje simple y con un humor ligeramente negro.

Considero que el entendimiento del autor sobre el Budismo es muy elemental y por lo mismo no del todo certero. Es ilustrativo estar conscientes de c√≥mo ha sido el desarrollo de la sociedad humana y su proceso de cognici√≥n. Por otra parte el Budismo no invita a suprimir los deseos, lo que hace es una invitaci√≥n a la reflexi√≥n sobre lo que verdaderamente es causa de la felicidad genuina y duradera. El Budadharma NO es una religi√≥n, desde el punto te√≠sta. Unas preguntas que el autor plantea y considero que son fundamentales como especie son; ¬øen qu√© deseamos convertirnos? y ¬øQu√© queremos desear?. Tambi√©n es importante la reflexi√≥n sobre el desequilibrio ecol√≥gico que la humanidad y su consumo est√° provocando. Finalmente es importante considerar que el ser humano mientras busque la felicidad fuera de s√≠ mismo , siempre se encontrara insatisfecho. El ser humano adem√°s de buscar conocimiento nuevo en disciplinas cient√≠ficas, debe ver hacia adentro y buscar urgentemente un crecimiento espiritual, encontrar la forma de hacer que conscientemente nazca y se incremente el altruismo a favor de todos los seres vivos. De otra forma, en mi opini√≥n lejos de evolucionar como "dioses insatisfechos" antes nos encontraremos con nuestra propia extinci√≥n.

Es un libro innovador. Los conceptos que maneja el autor son reveladores en muchos aspectos y nos da una perspectiva muy diferente de c√≥mo ver al ser humano a trav√©s del tiempo y su relaci√≥n con la Historia. La idea -la tesis- que se desarrolla durante todo el libro es lo interesante e importante, m√°s all√° de la narrativa anecd√≥tica en la que se desenvuelve.

Creo firmemente que este es uno de los mejores libros que tuve la oportunidad de leer. A trav√©s de su lectura, "Sapiens" te genera una nueva visi√≥n en tu forma de pensar y tu percepci√≥n del mundo en el que vivimos y como lo vivimos: te abre las puertas a una perspectiva completa de quienes somos en conjunto como especie.A trav√©s de sus 456 p√°ginas de lectura (tiene m√°s, pero son fuentes y referencias) el lector puede sumergirse en la intrincada historia del hombre desde su origen hasta el d√≠a de hoy, no solo desde una perspectiva antropol√≥gica, si no desde el punto de vista de la biolog√≠a, la historia, la psicolog√≠a, la sociolog√≠a y la perspectiva humana. Es un completo y ordenado an√°lisis del ser humano desde distintas disciplinas y como este se hizo valer como la especie dominante sobre la tierra, pero tambi√©n es una autocr√≠tica del camino autodestructivo que como especie en conjunto hemos tomado y la repercusi√≥n que hemos tenido en el planeta y en los seres con los que cohabitamos.Me ha gustado bastante la estructura ordenada que maneja el libro, desde su origen y como el sentido cr√≠tico que le ha otorgado a los momentos claves en su historia como especie y que lo ha catapultado hasta donde estamos actualmente, realizando un an√°lisis de acciones clave y de forma de pensar a medida que ganamos m√°s y m√°s inteligencia. Su lectura es agradable, y para nada cansada. A pesar de manejar gran cantidad de informaci√≥n el autor se las ingenia con humor moderado y sencillez para no atiborrar a su lector. Esta sencillez y la capacidad de abarcar partes importantes de la historia del hombre sin crear una sensaci√≥n de atiborramiento de informaci√≥n, as√≠ como su repercusi√≥n en ellas es lo que diferencia este libro de otros similares y que lo hace destacar sobre otros.Su lectura debe ser obligatoria para todo aqu√©l que desee comprender desde el punto de vista cient√≠fico que somos, de dnonde venimos y hac√≠a donde vamos. El libro resultar√° un gran cambio de perspectiva y abrir√° una nueva forma de ver el libro para su lector.Eso si, hay que tener cuidado: leer este libro debe hacerse desde un punto de vista imparcial y siempre con la mente abierta. Este es ante todo un ensayo del autor donde realiza un an√°lisis desde su perspectiva del ser humano, por lo que es normal encontrar conclusiones que coincidan o choquen con nuestros ideales y forma de pensar. Esto no le quita valor, si no todo lo contrario. In the shortest possible summary, let me start by saying that Behave is a stupendous book, and among the best science books I have read. While it is a book of science, and very detailed in parts at that ‚Äì it is still highly recommended reading for everybody. After all, who is not curious about why we behave the way we do. This book is certainly a tribute to the remarkable progress science has made in understanding our brain and our behaviours. However, be warned that it is a big book, which has a lot of detail and you might be in for a slower read than many other books.Robert Sapolsky invokes interest and curiosity right from the start - talking about how we are very conflicted in our beliefs ‚Äì especially we condone many acts of violence, but do support others. I have to admit I have many conflicts I am unable to resolve myself ‚Äì such as the fact that I find very impressive the progress that science has made as detailed in this book, and yet I am very pained that much of this has come with cruel experiments on animals.The organisation of the book is very logical ‚Äì it traces an action from when it happens, to moments before, months/years before and potentially several years earlier in cases. Experiments show that there are several markers in our brain which light up, before we take any action. So the big question (which the book Homo Deus by Yuval Noah Harari explores as well) ‚Äì do we really have free will? Do we have the ability to stop when the natural instinct kicks in? As it turns out, much of how we act is a result of a multitude of factors ‚Äì events which have happened at any time previously - sometimes well in the past, our genes, environment, and many others, some of it still to be determined. This has extremely important implications for law enforcement as well.There are excellent examples: eg: when you compliment a child on good work, telling them they are clever vs telling them they are hardworking invokes very different responses. While we appreciate empathy ‚Äì the ability to step into and feel the others experience, empathy stalls action. Compassion is more effective. The discussion around how the brain responds to meditation are alluded to ‚Äì though I think it deserved far more coverage. There are also other interesting lessons around how judges and juries decide punishment based on a number of factors which logic says should have no bearing.The issues of ‚ÄúUs‚Äù vs ‚ÄúThem‚Äù is discussed in detail, and deservedly so. Our brain instantly associates some faces as ‚ÄúUs‚Äù and some others as ‚ÄúThem‚Äù. We develop this categorisation over time and this association is very strong in adulthood and near impossible to get over. While this is true even in animals, our behaviours are more complex. The ‚ÄúUs‚Äù categorisation could be based on country, language, religion, colour, and others. The natural tendency is to think in terms of aggregate labels rather than as individuals, accounting for much of our biases.This is a big book, and one for which I should have taken notes. But I did not. Since there is a wealth of important information, I expect I will have to revisit the book again ‚Äì when I feel I am forgetting its contents.The Appendix has information on Brain / Genes / Hormones which is worth taking a look at. This is an exceptional book, though certainly not light reading. Since it packs great amount of detail, it is a more difficult read than for instance ‚ÄúSapiens‚Äù by Yuval Noah Harari. However, I very strongly recommend this ‚Äì for reading at the earliest possible

The book is really interesting but it's badly let down by weak, slangy writing. I'm just over 2/3 of the way through, and if I see the phrase 'stay tuned' again I think I will scream.WIth a better editor this could have been an excellent book. For example, someone really should have picked up on this paragraph: "The authors deconstructed high rank with three questions: (a) How many people ranked lower than the subject in his organization? (b) How much autonomy did he have (e.g., to hire and fire)? (c) How many people did he directly supervise? And high rank came with low glucocorticoids and anxiety only insofar as the position was about the first two variables‚Äîlots of subordinates, lots of authority. In contrast, having to directly supervise lots of subordinates did not predict those good outcomes."I'm pretty sure that should say "lots of autonomy, lots of authority". As it is, it states that lots of subordinates are both good and, "in contrast" bad. There are several errors like this, and they can be quite confusing.

This book is a well-made translation of the algorithmic thinking used by computer scientists into plain-English. I like the author's style of writing because it is straight to the point and accessible for laypeople. He make hard concepts easy to understand and uses a lot of examples throughout the book. Amazing piece of work!

This book talks about the history and evolution of algorithms from the very beginning, talking about particular problems and the different approaches scientists, mathematicians and others have adopted in trying to solve these issues. This book is clever in how it can get the reader to see a general problem and showing them how it can be broken down into different categories that a computer can solve, and how the thinking to solve that problems can solve other problems. This is a key skill to have in fields such as applied mathematics and computer science and gets the reader thinking about problems in the right way.

This was a great read, it made me grab my pen several times to jot down stuff that I wanted to look into further later on. There are several interesting topics discussed throughout the book including Bayes Theorem, Game Theory and Optimal Stopping problems. All topics I briefly had touched upon at school but long had forgotten, I really wish I had the authors as my teachers because they truly do engross you with their real-world practical examples! That and their humourous storytelling makes this something I really would recommend.

This is an outstanding book in those I have read recently. It's worthwhile from both perspectives: how computer science applies to other areas, but also in better understanding computer science concepts.

Como Steve Jobs, cruel, despiadado, d√©spota, inflexible, Elon Musk es alguien que en su vida se queda sin un centavo varias veces en la vida y finalmente es uno de los multimillonarios que tienen algo que todos queremos, pero no lo sab√≠amos.

Ready to learn from Netflix?I wrote a detailed summary in Chinese of ‚ÄúNo Rules Rules‚Äù by Netflix CEO Hastings and Prof. Meyer. In just one day half a million have clicked it. Over a thousand commented and re-blogged it. Too bad Netflix does not even operate in China (Beijing‚Äôs insecurity).In China, ‚Äúour HR management is light years behind‚Äù, many say. What struck them most are: (1) in a knowledge economy, flexibility and freedom are key for innovation and success. The idea of ‚Äúinformed captains‚Äù is attractive. (2) Hastings spends hundreds of hours a year talking to many staff, but bosses of a typical Chinese company isolate themselves. Too many executives spend too much time with customers and regulators. They are too busy to speak with even direct reports. Smart executives know the importance of managing employees but few are as meticulous and systematic as Hastings.At UBS, we hated 360-degree performance reviews. But Netflix made them work. Extreme candour at Netflix sounds good, but I haven‚Äôt seen a firm practise it.Skeptics ask, ‚Äúis it possible Netflix has succeeded despite its low-rule management?‚Äù But how do we analyse causality? ‚ÄúA randomised controlled study‚Äù?

This book is not only written in a very clear and engaging way but it is also maybe the best possible (and honest!) advice out there. No talking around the point and making things sound nice and pleasing to everyone - which is amazing and exactly what one wants.Every employee and employer should read this and apply the shared knowledge if they want to stay on top of what is an amazing working environment to thrive in and succeed as a company long-term.

A bit of a snooze and not enough content for a book. If you Google for the Netflix Culture deck you‚Äôll get pretty much the same content. Also, Patty McCord‚Äôs book covers the same ground.I guess I was hoping for ‚ÄòThe Story of Netflix‚Äô but this is very much a management book. Not bad but if you know the culture already then you won‚Äôt learn much.

I thought the book was going to be about the story of the rise and challenges of Netflix over the past 20 years but it's more of a management book, but that's on me and so haven't marked it down for that reason. Good read overall and well written. Makes me want to work for Netflix.

En mi generaci√≥n, somos muy conscientes de la importancia de la mente, pero Barret est√° vendiendo esta idea al extremo.Para ella, no hay reacci√≥n, no hay recepci√≥n de canales sensoriales, no hay conciencia de la entrada sensorial. Todo es predicci√≥n, incluso un olor inesperado. La lleva a la p√°gina 64 para aceptar procesos de recepci√≥n de entradas sensoriales menos pensadas, y tal reconocimiento casi no tiene eco en sus escritos. Para m√≠, es una especie de estiramiento ver la recepci√≥n sensorial (que por supuesto involucra al sistema nervioso, y puede ser contaminada eventualmente por la simulaci√≥n y la 'ilusi√≥n') como predicci√≥n, y la auto-conciencia como predicci√≥n.En resumen, su cerebro est√°, como ella dice, encerrado en su cr√°neo. Disfrut√© a fondo de este libro muy bien escrito. Su estilo de escritura es bastante f√°cil de leer, aunque est√° introduciendo algunos conceptos muy dif√≠ciles y desafiantes. Como un √°vido, aunque laico, lector de libros sobre neurociencia, psicolog√≠a y filosof√≠a, sus explicaciones en este libro superaron todo lo que pens√© que sab√≠a sobre el cerebro y la mente. Hay alguna repetici√≥n, pero personalmente me pareci√≥ √∫til porque el libro se siente como la construcci√≥n de un rompecabezas 3D, as√≠ que tener algunas ideas repetidas ayuda a orientarte a c√≥mo encajan las cosas.Definitivamente no una sola vez leer y luego dejarlo a un lado. Si est√° interesado en este tema, entonces en mi opini√≥n, este es uno de los mejores libros disponibles y por esa raz√≥n lo recomendar√≠a de todo coraz√≥n.

Tengo que darle a este libro 5 estrellas basadas en su audacia y ambici√≥n solamente.El autor desaf√≠a sin miedo algunos de los campos (psicolog√≠a afectiva/neurociencia) m√°s venerados y respetados te√≥ricos e investigadores, incluyendo Jack Panksap, Antonio Damassio, Joseph LeDoux, Paul Ekman e incluso Charles Darwin.Eso es loco.El libro es un matadero virtual de vacas sagradas.Tengo reservas sobre muchas de las afirmaciones de los autores. Es dif√≠cil no hacerlo, porque ella desaf√≠a mucho del evangelio actual.Dicho esto, tengo la fuerte intuici√≥n de que este trabajo representa un desaf√≠o leg√≠timo al viejo paradigma.Ser√° interesante leer el inevitable retroceso.

Una mirada muy interesante de c√≥mo Lisa cree actualmente que nuestros cerebros crean nuestras emociones. Lisa empuja bien contra la marea de creencias establecidas y hace un buen caso para sus teor√≠as.Pero, probablemente lanzaremos este en el ¬´raspar la cabeza de las ideas cient√≠ficas salvajes que vinieron y se fueron¬ª dentro de unos a√±os, junto con todos los otros pensamientos que actualmente se adaptan a la zeitgeist.Interesante sin embargo.

Este no es un libro f√°cil de leer. Varias veces consider√© rendirme, pero realmente quer√≠a entender el tema, as√≠ que continu√©. Y me alegro de haberlo hecho, la segunda mitad del libro no s√≥lo fue iluminador, sino tambi√©n verdaderamente interesante. Hab√≠a muchos ejemplos fascinantes de estudios e historias de casos, una visi√≥n muy esclarecedora del derecho penal (tanto en los Estados Unidos como en el Reino Unido) con respecto a las acciones inconscientes, y una visi√≥n de las sugerencias de que los animales podr√≠an experimentar emociones.Como insinu√© antes, la primera mitad del libro fue un trabajo muy duro. Es cierto que algunos de los conceptos son muy complejos y dif√≠ciles de entender. Sent√≠ que la autora estaba decidida a conducir a casa cada detalle de su considerable investigaci√≥n sobre los roles de predicci√≥n y error de predicci√≥n en la formaci√≥n de nuestras emociones con el fin de desmantelar completamente la visi√≥n cl√°sica de las emociones ¬´esenciales¬ª generadas por regiones espec√≠ficas del cerebro. Esto es completamente comprensible ya que el desarrollo de una teor√≠a de predicci√≥n de la funci√≥n del cerebro ha sido claramente una parte importante de su carrera profesional.Y este libro es muy convincente de sus teor√≠as. El autor es talentoso, articulado y dedicado y este libro es probablemente uno de los an√°lisis modernos m√°s exhaustivos de c√≥mo se crean las emociones. La primera mitad del libro fue una historia muy interesante de la evoluci√≥n de los n√∫meros como los usamos hoy en d√≠a. Imag√≠nese tratando de hacer multiplicaci√≥n o divisi√≥n larga usando n√∫meros romanos.Un concepto que me encant√≥ fue que la ¬´invenci√≥n de la contabilidad¬ª para hacer un seguimiento de los gastos y los beneficios era tan importante, si no m√°s, que la Revoluci√≥n Industrial.En la √∫ltima parte del libro el Autor muestra que no entiende la evoluci√≥n de los Derivados o sus usos.

Probabilidad para el profano. Libro ambicioso, gran contar historias, pero el tema es tan masivo que s√≥lo rasca la superficie. A√∫n as√≠, es f√°cil de leer y nos ayuda a dejar de lado cualquier concepto err√≥neo sobre la probabilidad y las estad√≠sticas. Buen libro.

A pesar de haber sido publicado en 1996 este libro, sus conceptos y discusiones siguen siendo muy relevantes en 2013. Bernstein retrata magistralmente la cuantificaci√≥n del riesgo como un arte que no es una ciencia exacta desde el principio, a pesar de la predilecci√≥n de la gente por creer lo contrario. El cap√≠tulo sobre The Theory Police es particularmente interesante, ya que cuestiona los modelos econ√≥micos neocl√°sicos usando el trabajo de Daniel Kahneman, 15 a√±os antes de que Thinking Fast & Slow de Kahneman se convirtiera en un bestseller.Muy recomendable para cualquier persona interesada en los modelos de gesti√≥n de riesgos, pero puede conceptualizar que, dado que los datos anteriores son un requisito previo, ning√∫n modelo puede tener en cuenta perfectamente los riesgos imprevistos.

¬´A y B est√°n jugando un juego limpio de balla. Est√°n de acuerdo en continuar hasta que uno haya ganado seis rondas. El juego se detiene cuando A ha ganado cinco y B tres. ¬øC√≥mo deben dividirse las apuestas?¬ªNo hasta 1654 ser√≠a una respuesta a la pregunta anterior finalmente ser descubierto cuando el abogado franc√©s y matem√°tico aficionado Pierre de Fermat uni√≥ fuerzas con el matem√°tico franc√©s Blaise Pascal. ¬´Contra los Dioses: La Notable Historia del Riesgo¬ª de Peter Bernstein traza no s√≥lo su relaci√≥n, sino la historia completa de la comprensi√≥n del hombre de la probabilidad y el riesgo y las vidas de los muchos pensadores que la exploraron.El libro sigue el desarrollo de las matem√°ticas elementales modernas, la probabilidad, la distribuci√≥n, la gesti√≥n de riesgos, la teor√≠a de juegos, el comportamiento humano y termina con una visi√≥n general del papel del riesgo en los instrumentos financieros. En primer lugar, el libro ofrece una visi√≥n completa del papel hist√≥rico de los juegos de azar y el desarrollo del sistema num√©rico utilizado hoy por los pensadores hind√∫-√°rabes y Fibonacci. En segundo lugar, sigue el desarrollo de la probabilidad de Pacciloi, Cardano, Hyugen, Leibniz, Graunt, Pascal y Fermet y el desarrollo de las estad√≠sticas de Graunt, Petty y Halley. En tercer lugar, el papel de la distribuci√≥n normal, la varianza y la regresi√≥n a la media se introduce a trav√©s de las obras de Moivre, Bayes, Gauss, Laplace, Galton, Quetlet y Cornot, mientras que Bernoulli, Bentham, Jevons introducen la importancia de la utilidad. En cuarto lugar, el papel de la gesti√≥n moderna de riesgos en las carteras se introduce a trav√©s de la varianza y la diversificaci√≥n por las obras de Bachelier y Markowitz, mientras que Thaler, Kanheman y Tversky introducen el papel del comportamiento humano realista frente a la suposici√≥n de racionalidad humana. Por √∫ltimo, el papel de los instrumentos financieros modernos se introduce mediante la creaci√≥n de la f√≥rmula de precios de opci√≥n Black-Scholes y el papel de los derivados tanto en la reducci√≥n como en la exacerbaci√≥n del riesgo.Bernstein proporciona un relato animado de la historia matem√°tica de la probabilidad y el riesgo que pone los avances de las matem√°ticas modernas en perspectiva, pero decepcionantemente no hace hincapi√© realmente en la importancia de sus descubrimientos. Bernstein tiene un estilo de escritura similar de Robert Heilbroner en los Wordly Philosophers y Bill Bryson en A short History of Nearly Everything con la capacidad de no s√≥lo transmitir el significado de ideas complejas, sino tambi√©n de explorar la humanidad de aquellos detr√°s de ellos en el contexto de su tiempo y lugar en la historia. Sin embargo, el libro no explica la importancia de estos descubrimientos, mencionando brevemente su importancia en los mercados financieros a trav√©s del desarrollo de la diversificaci√≥n de la cartera y el aumento de los derivados. ¬øQu√© pasa con el uso de la estad√≠stica y la probabilidad en Medicina, Biolog√≠a, F√≠sica y otros campos cient√≠ficos y mucho menos la inclusi√≥n de la estad√≠stica en una pl√©tora de aspectos de la vida cotidiana?Sin embargo, abra un libro de texto universitario sobre estad√≠sticas despu√©s de leer ¬´Contra los dioses¬ª y Bernstein inyecta un soplo de aire fresco, colocando las f√≥rmulas tomadas por sentado en el contexto de cuatro siglos de pensamiento matem√°tico.

Gran introducci√≥n a la historia del riesgo.Bernstein es ciertamente culpable de cierto grado de esnobismo cronol√≥gico, especialmente en los primeros cap√≠tulos, y de simplificaci√≥n excesiva (en el mejor de los casos, o malentendido, en el peor) de los puntos de vista te√≠stas del riesgo. Esto puede ser un poco molesto. Sin embargo, si usted puede ver m√°s all√° de esto y tomar algunas de sus declaraciones barridas con una pizca de sal, hace que sea una buena y minuciosa lectura. Ciertamente recomendado.
Se trata de una aportaci√≥n original y erudita que presenta el tema del riesgo desde una perspectiva hist√≥rica y economista. Este libro alimentar√° al riesgo hambriento y estimular√° a los curiosos.

At some points, Styxx had it worse.His character arc within the other books does come to make sense with this book. What I don‚Äôt understand is why people (characters and other readers included) have come to hat Acheron. I‚Äôll admit that what he‚Äôs done in the books is disturbing, but he punishes himself enough. He‚Äôs also not all-knowing, which the characters in the book happen to know (as do the reviewers, though opinions alway differ).I do love Styxx towards the end of the novel. His growth and maturation is well crafted and the pacing of the novel is okay, despite its length. I am however, a little aggravated by the constant repetition within some of the novels. It doesn‚Äôt feel new, just recycled, which is why it has been given only three stars.

Having pre-ordered this book on my kindle a while back I read the lastest instalment of the Dark Hunter world with bated breath as I had not been so impressed with the last couple of books that Kenyon wrote. However, Styxx has to be one of the best yet, and I particularly enjoyed reading the authors note at the beginning as Kenyon is upfront about the fact that there is no documented history on the time that she is writing about for Styxx and Acheron's pasts. I enjoyed reading this book and think that it is the standout along with Acheron as the best two books in the series. The detail in the writing describing Styxx past and how it differs so greatly from what Acheron has always said about his brother is spectacular and it really captures the pain that he felt. I would recommend this book to anyone but warn them to read the rest of the series' first before they delve into this as it answers a lot of unsolves questions about Styxx and about why he played his part in earlier books and how he was persuaded to join the Dark Hunters fight against Stryker.

I don't think I can describe how this book made me feel... It's also hard to say much about it without spoiling it, so I'm not going to go into the story's twists and turns (and there were alot!) Acheron was a hard book to read and man did you wanna murder Styxx in it for what he did to Ash... But then you read Styxx and you are blown away. No one knew Styxx, I don't think anyone saw this book coming. It is heartbreaking. Truly heartbreaking. He had it worse than Ash. He really truly did. I actually hated Ash in this book for what happened to Styxx and even at the end I wasn't 100% certain I wanted to forgive him, even though he deserved forgiveness. Total new perspective. Absolute must read for those who have followed these books from the beginning and for new comers to the world of the Dark-Hunters.My only complaint (while I was reading it) would be that while reading it (on my Kindle) I was ever conscious of the fact that I was getting further and further into the book and we were still in Ancient Greece/Atlantis. I kept wanting to know when we'd hit the modern era - like in Ash's book - and see Styxx and Beth, Styxx and Ash etc in the present. It was incredibly frustrating when reading thinking that it would all be rushed and it was because I was expecting it to be like Ash's book. This isn't Ash's book and Styxx and Beth didn't need to meet and fall in love like Ash and Tory, they never stopped being in love and that was my mistake.I would've liked more time in the present but I can't wait for a re-read now I know I don't have to worry about the amount of time in Ancient Greece taking away from Styxx's future as - with all Kenyon's books - our man gets the future he deserves in the end, and it was wonderful... Even if the amount of abuse in this book makes it hard to read at times.I can't wait to see Styxx in further releases, he totally stole my heart.

From the very beginning I said I loved Styxx, there was just something about him that I knew I loved and that what we was seeing wasn't exactly true to why he was doing the things he was,My friend who is the 1 to get me on Kenyon books said she didn't like him at all and his such a d**k but I said nope your wrong, watch an see.... welllllll when we read this she looked at me and said " you was right" üòÜüòÜüòÜüòÑüòÑüòÑCould not put it down just amazing and he isn't what he was portrayed to see

Holy wow!!! That's all I can say!!! What an amazing, heart wrenching, turbulent ride. Styxx was the absolute bad guy in Acheron but when you read the story from his side - Oh my goodness!! Everything is turned on its head. This book reduced me to tears, hell not tears - full out ugly ugly crying!!! If you like the Dark-Hunters, you have to read this book. It will put you through the wringer but it is an amazing, heart breaking and ultimately up lifting story.

I found that this was a really hard read. The content of the first about 65-70% was truly heartbreaking. I personally feel that there should have been a warning about the content before starting reading it. There was a very high torture and rape content which to be honest I found too much at times. I felt that it went a bit too far and on too long; I got the point that he had a horrendously abusive childhood and was treated badly by almost everyone.I was reading it at the same time as a friend and we‚Äôre both avid Dark Hunter readers, I admit that if I hadn‚Äôt been able to share my feelings with her whilst reading I am not sure I would have been able to get through the Ancient Greek time period.Acheron was not nice in this book and I‚Äôd go as far as saying I actually really disliked him intently. Seeing Ryssa from Styxx‚Äôs point of view actually made me glad the way circumstances unfolded, she was a rather dislikeable person. A complete turnabout as she was great in Acheron.However, once we progressed from the nightmare that was Styxx‚Äôs early life it moved to a more typical Dark Hunter novel and reading it was much easier. He more than deserved his HEA.I can‚Äôt say that I enjoyed this novel because that feels wrong after everything that happened within it. I did enjoy Styxx getting his HEA and some of the unexpected moments during the early part of the book. Whilst the writing was excellent, and it was great to finally see the truth behind Styxx, but in the main it was too hard to read.

Well I did not expect that!I'll try not to give away any spoilers, but apologies in advance if I get a bit too specific with anything. Read at your own risk i guess because I'm not sure how much I can contain.So, if you've read Acheron (and if you're reading this then surely you must have) you'll know that Styxx so far has been presented as a spoiled and rather cruel figure, envious and scared of Acheron which had led to trouble making. This book really does explain away most of what we see and really gives a solid definition to 'point of view'.From Acherons point of view, yes, Styxx is a spoiled and cruel person with no regard for anything but himself and his father. From Styxx's point of view, there is a lot more to it than that.I came into this book with one brown firmly quirked expecting to see a lot of bad with a little bit of good and some redemption style story towards the end of it. I was completely off base with that expectation. Bottom line, Styxx is really not that bad, he's just extremely misunderstood and has had to made a number of hard choices to protect those around it - and at times those choices have left him looking like a no good villain.Acheron, as we know, had an extremely violent and traumatic past. Styxx is a damn close second to Acherons suffering childhood, only a lot of it happens behind closed doors. Like Acherons story, this dragged me in and held me until it was over, and I'm not ashamed to say it made me weepy once or twice.Best advice I can offer is to go into this without any expectations and be prepared to turn around any opinion you may have formed of Styxx and of Acheron before now. And I do truly mean that, my opinion of Acheron changed rather dramatically by the end of this book.

Okay, first things first. This book does contain some rather excessive abuse, (physical, sexual and emotional) so please take this into consideration when purchasing. And although I hated reading this it is probably a must in order to make this book so completely amazing. I wasn't going to make such a disclaimer until reading some other reviews and being reminded of the trauma this could possibly cause to some. So just wanted to give fair warning. However I feel that the way these truly heart-wrenching scenes are written and the obvious LOVE that Sherrilyn has for her characters more than make up for such distressing scenes.Now onto what I wanted to say. Before reading this book I was prepared to hate Styxx, if not already halfway there. I was also prepared not to love this book (although fairly sure that would not be the case being a Sherrilyn Kenyon book). What I was not prepared for was to love Styxx and in some places be very close to hating Acheron (please forgive me Ash) but that is what happened. I really can't decide which twin I like best now so I will just say I love both equally. Poor, poor Styxx how you've been wronged not to mention miss-understood. Well done Sherrilyn for uncovering such a travesty and getting Styxx's story out, even at such cost to Ash.This amazing book had me in tears more than any I can remember. It took me on a journey that brought out so many differing emotional responses. From making my chest ache both in sadness and joy to everything in between. This book is as real as fiction gets if not more so. I know this isn't real and yet it is in my heart. What an excellent writer to make something so fantastical feel so real and so utterly believable. This does not feel like fiction at all you are right there with Styxx all throughout wanting your own god powers to smite all his enemies.I could talk about this book for hours but don't want to spoil this journey for others by giving too much away. One final thing I must say though is. Thank you Sherrilyn so so much for restoring my faith in books. The majority of the ones I've read lately even the really good ones have not managed to keep me guessing until the end like a good book should. I have unfortunately been figuring things out way too soon yet Styxx kept me puzzling right to the end and threw some really good surprises. Wow.Absolutely LOVED IT and can't wait for the next book.

for fans of SH this book is not to be missed i couldnt stop reading i was so drawn into styxx's world and i was so shocked at his life, some parts were hard to read they were so shocking and emotional i had couldnt help but cry for him as his life seemed so much worse than acherons.ive felt like i was on a rollercoaster reading this story, i laughed and cried all the way throughout the book and i couldnt put it down. part of the story is about styxx's past is in ancient greece and the other part is in the present and linked to the times that styxx has been mentioned in past books. This is a great story thats so visual and full of action, love, hope and despair and not all in that order.all the characters were great and so visual i felt everything they feltandi think every past character is in this book and it was great to hear fom them especially savitar. I cant to read the next installment of the DH series.

Amelia is enjoying a weekend in New York with her friend, Zara, to take her mind off overthinking why her boyfriend, Jake, broke up with her out of the blue. They are approached by two men, Nick and Jordan, and enjoy their night drinking away.The book flashbacks to Amelia's story of trying to get over Jay, as he keeps her dangling on a string while he's off enjoying himself. Further on, you hear Jordan ranting about games women are playing - one minute very interested and the next minute you're ghosted!This book is a take on male and female perceptions of love and relationships in the modern world - with Tinder and Bumble making it easier for people to hook up - never knowing if they want more and being too afraid to ask incase you scare them off.I loved this book and read it in one sitting. I've highlighted so many passages as I relate to it so well! This is a book for all single women, and maybe men too! This one has earned a permanent spot on my shelf!

La vida de Grace cambi√≥ despu√©s de que sus padres murieron en un accidente automovil√≠stico, y as√≠, por la vida que est√° acostumbrada a ella se muda a la congelada Alaska para ir a su internado de T√≠os, pero descubre que tiene que lidiar con problemas mucho mayores que el fr√≠o.Realmente disfrut√© este libro, cuando empec√© a leerlo me acord√© mucho de Crep√∫sculo y al llegar a trav√©s del libro vi las similitudes a√∫n m√°s con todo el chico malo que quiere mantenerse alejado de ella pero no puede y c√≥mo ella siempre est√° en peligro. Tambi√©n vi muchas similitudes con el programa de televisi√≥n Legacies que en realidad se hizo referencia en el libro.Me gust√≥ que aunque hab√≠a muchos personajes que a menudo pueden ser confusos, Tracy los present√≥ en el momento adecuado, me encant√≥ la expectativa de que Grace descubriera la verdad. Tengo que decir que no esperaba el giro de la trama al final y qui√©n estaba detr√°s de todo, pero lo hizo mejor y el cliffhanger al final me excita por el mejor libro.En general, disfrut√© mucho de este libro, era una linda historia con la cantidad correcta de acci√≥n. Todo para mantenerte interesado. Definitivamente recomendar√≠a. 4.5/5 ‚≠êÔ∏è
