¬øQu√© es esto...??Los personajes no son personajes, son meros contornos, y todos los dem√°s en el libro tienen espacio en blanco. Nada se desarrolla natural o org√°nicamente, las descripciones del autor de la gente y el lugar no est√°n integradas en la historia en absoluto (esto se vuelve m√°s divertido cuando se empieza a notar), no hay caracterizaci√≥n consistente, y si el h√©roe del libro no era atractivo, este ser√≠a un libro sobre un asesino en serie. Lo que tambi√©n me pareci√≥ divertido, y solo puedes leer este libro si est√°s preparado para re√≠r, es que cualquier otro personaje femenino aparte de Nora y su madre se describe como gordo, feo, viejo o una prostituta. El silencio es donde el feminismo va a morir. El √∫nico rasgo de car√°cter de Vee es que tiene sobrepeso, muy codiciosa, y no tiene disciplina para una dieta; Marcie es desestimada como ¬´anor√©xica¬ª y su delgadez parece servir como prueba de su superficialidad y crueldad. Vee y Marcie son opuestos polares; Vee nunca es una amenaza para Nora porque es gorda, y Marcie es la amenaza y el ¬´enemigo¬ª porque es delgada.Durante la clase de ¬´biolog√≠a¬ª (utilizo ese t√©rmino sin tener en cuenta su contenido), la discusi√≥n sobre el sexo se basa enteramente en atraer a un compa√±ero para las relaciones sexuales procreativas. Los roles de Men vs. Women se establecen r√°pidamente, y el maestro pregunta a Patch c√≥mo se acercar√≠a a un ¬´compa√±ero potencial¬ª en una fiesta, y constantemente se implica que los hombres son los perseguidores y las mujeres s√≥lo tienen la opci√≥n de aceptar o rechazar. As√≠ que en la novela ser un acosador se ve como una prueba de deseo, m√°s que como no consensual. Nada es consistente en este libro, aparte de la estupidez y la inmadurez de los personajes, que alcanzan en ciertos puntos para ser casi dolorosos. El momento clim√°tico de la novela descansa en que los dos personajes principales est√°n enamorados, pero no hay evidencia ni base para esto, solo deseo sexual sin resolver. Los personajes son de papel fino, la trama es un desastre, y la escritura pobre. Sin embargo, es un libro divertido y se puede ver los ingredientes de un buen libro YA luchando por tomar forma. El segundo libro es el m√°s pobre de la serie, mientras que en el tercer y cuarto libros las cosas se vuelven cada vez m√°s claras. Leer√≠a esta serie con una pizca de sal, reconociendo la farsa junto a los momentos de s√≥lido contenido YA.

Hush, Hush is basically an angelic imitation of Twilight. Nora is made to sit next to a moody teenage boy ‚Äì Patch ‚Äì in school and finds herself drawn to him despite (or because of) the aura of danger around him. The parallels with Twilight are many, and are laughable. She even googles what she thinks is going on, exactly like Bella does with Edward. There are so many flaws: Nora doesn‚Äôt even bat an eyelid at the fact that Patch is possibly a fallen angel, and deals remarkably well with multiple people trying to kill her. In fact, she manages to maintain her focus on her attraction to Patch throughout the entire book. The girl has questionable priorities but fantastic concentration.I actually did quite like Nora. She‚Äôs surprisingly un-whiney for a YA protagonist, and Patch is an incredibly clich√©d but likeable character. Looking back, the story is actually pretty awful. Not much happens; almost the whole book is about Nora and Patch‚Äôs blossoming romance, with very little actually being about angels and whatnot. Yet, I really enjoyed it. It‚Äôs hard to pinpoint what I actually enjoyed about this book because I‚Äôm not even sure what was going on for half of it, but I couldn‚Äôt put it down. Maybe I‚Äôm just a sucker for a paranormal YA romance, all I know is I loved it and will definitely be reading book #2.

I read this book a few years back and totally became pulled into the whole series. It became one of my favourite YA. Rereading it now, I realise that I am just as taken as I was before.Patch is a bad boy with an air of mystery surrounding him. I must admit that he isn't very pleasant at the begenning, but when he brings out his other side, he is rather lovable.Nora is a good student who is still traumatised by the loss of a loved one. She is naive at times and I guess that what makes her who she is.Meeting for the first time in a biology class, Patch and Nora start to butt heads. This happens to be his favourite pastime. She knows that there is something not quite right about him, but she finds herself drawn to him regardless. Strange things start to happen and Nora appears to be in a state of paranoia. Is she though? When her life is really in danger, she discovers all the mysteries surrounding hers and Patch's life.This story builds up slowly and if I hadn't read it before, I might have given up. It's worth persevering. As it develops it has a pull that gives the urge to know what happens next. It's a good introduction to the series. A good take on the angel trope.

Hush Hush is another book I‚Äôve had on my radar for quite a while, it has been recommended to me by quite a few people who know I have a bit of an obsession with YA series.Hush Hush then centres around Nora, a 16 year old high school student who is, against her wishes, teamed up with new boy Patch for a school project. Patch is dark and mysterious (of course, and yay) and seems to be able to get into her head. He also starts turning up a lot wherever Nora is and strange events begin to occur that has Nora wondering if she is going slightly insane. Patch of course has a secret‚Ä¶.Thoroughly enjoyed this one ‚Äì Fallen Angels are popular lately in YA and this is an excellent example of when that particular story is done really really well. Great characters (Both Nora and Patch are intriguing in their own way) a terrific supporting cast and some beautifully done descriptive prose makes this one pop.One thing I particularly liked about Hush Hush was that it was not in a rush to get anywhere. Becca Fitzpatrick takes the time to give her characters background, depth and feeling, hooking you into their world and making you care. Still, there is always plenty going on even if we don‚Äôt get to the crux of the matter until later in the story. The end is then one of hectic thrilling excitement that works brilliantly.Overall then a scintillating read. I‚Äôm very happy that I ordered the whole series together. Because I‚Äôm looking forward very much to seeing what is going to happen next.Happy Reading Folks**Source; Purchased Copy**

I have mixed feelings about this book. For some reason I seem to love books about fallen angels, I guess it's the whole love being more important than absolutely anything else thing. As they go I did quite like this one. I found the way angels etc. were portrayed was interesting, not over theological or all feathers and glory and perfection. It meant that there was a grittiness to the book. There was an element of thriller that I hadn't expected and I enjoyed not knowing what was going to happen and who to trust.What I enjoyed less was the romance. There was such confusion in this book as to who was good or bad, innocent or scheming. So when it came to the burgeoning romance I just couldn't see it, on either side. I felt no undeniable bond or passion between them, no tenderness and certainly no trust. Consequently I had no surge of relief or tear in my eye at the end. I kind of felt cheated out of the love part. Maybe it more of a feature in book two, or maybe I'm expecting too much of a young adult book, or maybe it just needed a bit more time spent developing a bond for us readers to feel. I get why we were supposed to doubt, that was the whole point of the book, but for me although the plot resolved it relied upon me believing in an emotion I didn't really feel was created.To sum up, this was interesting and an addictive read but not enough coherence of emotion for me to feel a deep connection with the characters or the romance.

My friend had been bugging me to read this book for a while now, probably since not long after it came out. However, I was very reluctant to do so. Why? Because I've never really been overly keen on the speculation of Angels in general. I don't have a proper, detailed explanation as to my being opposed to them - however I do think it has something to do with the fact that I'm not religious - at all. It's not that I have anything against religion; it's just never been my cup of tea. I suppose when I think of Angels, I think of God and the pearly white gates and I couldn't seem to separate the two. When I first started reading Hush, Hush, I didn't have my hopes up and wasn't expecting much. However, I was pleasantly surprised and really enjoyed reading it - so much so, that I read it in only three sittings.Ever since Nora Gray's Biology teacher re-assigned the class seating arrangements and she was placed next to Patch, the brooding new kid - things have been happening around her. Things she can't explain. Nora is drawn to Patch from the start. It's not just his dashing good looks - there's something dark and mysterious about him - something Nora wants to desperately find out. As she learns more and more about Patch and his dark past - Nora can't decide whether to fling herself into his arms, or run and hide.Nora's character was quite interesting. She wasn't the most in depth character I've read; however, her character narrated the book very well and made it quite a pleasure to read. Nora is just your typical teenage girl; worrying about what clothes to wear, messing around with her best friend and trying to pass her exams. Although Nora's character was generally stated as a girl who doesn't care much about boys in general, she falls - against her better judgement - for Patch, a new student who has suddenly has become her new Biology partner.Patch is tall, dark and mysterious - every girls dream, right? Yet Nora also finds him slightly threatening and dangerous. She does her best to stay away from him, yet finds he crops up wherever she goes. It wasn't until I was nearing the last 70 pages of this book that I actually started liking Patch's character. He was too rude, too arrogant and honestly; he just really irritated me. Even though I didn't like Patch at the beginning, I found myself constantly rooting for Patch and Nora to get together - don't ask me why...Although most of the time Nora is pretty much petrified of Patch, and is constantly trying to figure out whether he's starting to stalk her - her plan to keep away from him fails. This really irritated me. Yes, she felt a strong pull towards Patch, yes he's smoking hot and you wouldn't mind taking him for a few laps. But honestly, girl - if you think he's dangerous, so much so that you're getting paranoid and mentally accusing him of different crimes - you avoid him! I can't help comparing Patch to Edward Cullen, although Patch doesn't tell Nora to stay away from him (like Edward does), they're both giving off dangerous vibes, yet the female characters are drawn to them. Isn't it our natural instinct to flee from danger? Doesn't Nora have the fight or flight button programmed into her like everyone else?Anyway, apart from my irritations with Nora's actions at times, I did like her character overall. Every character has its flaws and rough edges. By the time I was ending the book, I'd warmed up to Patch's character - he didn't make me swoon and faint on the floor, but he turned out to be a pretty likeable guy. The last two characters I'd like to introduce are Vee and Elliot. Vee is Nora's best friend. Her BFF, they share clothes, cars and love to talk about pretty much everything. Vee's character wasn't that well developed in my opinion; however I don't think it really mattered. I do think that she was too easily swayed by the good looks of a guy and would rather tell her best friend that she's crazy than admit that Nora has a stalker - which annoyed the hell out of me. Overall, she seemed like a reasonable character and I loved her connection with Nora - it was incredible.Moving onward to Elliot, not long after Patch became Nora's Bio partner, he transfers from an Elite School in which he held a scholarship, to the regular high school Nora and Vee go to. Elliot starts off seeming like a stand up guy, quickly becoming friendly with the girls and hanging out with them. Nora even admits to liking him at the start until she ends up spending more time with Patch. Right from the start I never liked Elliot. He seemed like a slimy, stuck up worm that wanted to latch onto any pretty girl he could. Yet, that's probably me being too judgemental of him in general. Pretty much wherever Elliot went, his friend from his old school, Jules followed in the background, not speaking much at all.Overall I thought the characters were amazing and very interesting - even the ones I didn't like were very well thought out. I loved the way Nora's and Patch's relationship wasn't so cheesy and insta-love, which, if it was, would have ruined the book in my opinion. It wasn't exaggerated and overdone and kept in balance with the plot line well. There were so many different twists and turns throughout this book, it kept me completely on edge, constantly wondering what would happen next. I debated around quite a bit about whether to give this book 4/5 stars or 5/5. In the end I settled for the 4/5 stars, mainly because I felt there were a lot of loose ends that the book didn't tie up - and my irritations towards the characters idiocy at times. I think Becca Fitzpatrick is a great writer and I can't wait to get my hands on the sequel to this book.

Puede que no sea capaz de mostrar c√≥mo se siente pero no est√° a punto de permitir que le pase nada a Leila. Podr√≠an estar en desacuerdo sobre muchas cosas, pero se proteger√°n entre s√≠, ¬°pase lo que pase! Es frustrante verlos constantemente golpeando cabezas. Ninguno de ellos est√° preparado para ceder ante el otro. ¬øPueden llegar a un compromiso o est√°n sus mundos demasiado separados?No hay un momento aburrido en esta entrega. El peligro est√° en todas partes. Hay traici√≥n. La acci√≥n y el suspenso son implacables. Las interacciones entre Vlad y Leila son argumentos acalorados o sexo caliente chisporroteante. Hay humor, amor y risa tambi√©n. No hace falta decir que disfrut√© mucho leyendo esta novela y no puedo esperar a quedarme atascado en la siguiente.

Este libro tirar√° de las cuerdas de tu coraz√≥n viciosamente, y me encant√≥.La tensi√≥n se calienta en este libro cuando Leila exige m√°s compromiso de Vlad - para que sean algo o nada - y se involucra m√°s personalmente en la vieja disputa de Vlad.Hay algunas escenas oscuras de tortura en este libro que fueron manejadas bien. Vemos, sentimos y experimentamos lo suficiente de las aflicciones del personaje para saber c√≥mo se siente. Hab√≠a puntos en los que estaba a punto de desgarrar. Pero tampoco vemos demasiado. En realidad son los elementos menos gr√°ficos donde se ha retenido la tortura lo que me resulta m√°s inc√≥modo leer. Aunque me gusta este estilo de escribir sobre un tema oscuro, los detalles m√°s escasos en lugares significaban que las partes eran ambiguas y no entend√≠a lo que significaba la descripci√≥n desnuda. Con todo, sin embargo, este lado de la trama fue un √©xito.Rom√°nticamente, tenemos desgarro, traici√≥n, amor, escenas desgarradoras y sexo caliente humeante.

Vlad ha mantenido su distancia de Leila desde que sus habilidades ps√≠quicas comenzaron a jugar cuando la rode√≥ en su aura para salvarla de una explosi√≥n. Leila se preocupa de que sus habilidades defectuosas signifiquen que ya no est√© interesado, y preocuparse por lo que esto significa para un futuro, hasta que Vlad haga un anuncio impactante. ¬°Vlad se lo est√° proponiendo! Desafortunadamente, Leila se equivoca, y se da cuenta de que nunca est√° en las cartas para ella y Vlad, que nunca sentir√° por ella como ella siente por √©l. Humillada y herida, decide irse y volver a su antigua vida como acr√≥bata de carnaval con Marty. Pero cuando una bomba explota su antiguo remolque, parece que alguien la quiere muerta, y Vlad parece un posible sospechoso.¬° Oh, Vlad! Yo s√≠ lo amo. √âl es tan complicado cuando se trata de sus sentimientos. Puede actuar fr√≠o y distante, ¬°pero hay tantas cosas pasando debajo de la superficie! Sabes, no pens√© que fuera posible, pero √©l es a√∫n m√°s arrogante en este libro, ¬°y me pareci√≥ tan sorprendente! Debido a que el Vlad que conocemos de la serie Night Huntress es siempre bastante broma y coqueta, siempre he asumido que su arrogancia era mitad broma - seguro que hab√≠a algo all√≠, pero √©l no se tom√≥ demasiado en serio. Aunque de alguna manera ese puede ser el caso, su arrogancia es en su mayor√≠a real. Sin embargo, su arrogancia est√° realmente justificada; es Vlad el empalador, ha conquistado a muchos enemigos a lo largo de los siglos de su vida, ha pasado por terribles pruebas, sin embargo siempre sale a la cima. ¬øPor qu√© creer√≠a algo diferente? Y tiene m√°s de 500 a√±os, as√≠ que tiene ciertos ideales anticuados, y con su arrogancia, a veces puede parecer un poco irrazonable, pero Leila est√° bien para el desaf√≠o de ense√±arle el error de sus costumbres.Twice Tempted se sent√≠a un poco diferente a otros libros que he le√≠do por Frost. Se sent√≠a menos lleno de acci√≥n - tenga en cuenta el √©nfasis en ¬´fieltro¬ª Mirando hacia atr√°s, hay un buen n√∫mero de escenas de acci√≥n llenas de suspenso, emocionantes, sin embargo, cuando pienso en el libro en general, se sent√≠a m√°s un libro m√°s tranquilo, uno m√°s emocional - pero no exactamente deprimente o demasiado sacudo. Deben ser los problemas emocionales de cada d√≠a del libro, y ellos, para m√≠, parec√≠an superar el peligro. Pero cuando las cosas se resolvieron, parec√≠a suceder r√°pidamente. ¬øPosiblemente un poco demasiado f√°cil? Tal vez.Pero por lo dem√°s, una historia incre√≠ble! As√≠ que esperamos con inter√©s el tercer libro de la trilog√≠a para ver lo que sucede a continuaci√≥n!

Una vez m√°s disfrut√© de seguir la historia de amor de Vlad y luchar contra sus enemigos. Sin embargo, me encant√≥ ¬´Una vez quemado¬ª mucho m√°s y el final de este segundo libro me dej√≥ un poco molesto por la esposa de Vlad. Con todo, me encanta Vlad y esto es un muy bueno y debe leer para todos los amantes del romance paranormal!!!!!

Bueno, acabo de terminar este libro que es el segundo libro de la serie y es a√∫n m√°s apasionante que el primero. Otra vez lo termin√© en un d√≠a, ya que no pude dejarlo. Despu√©s de ayudar a VALD a tratar de localizar qui√©n est√° tratando de matarlo y su VALD le da una peque√±a caja que ella cree que es un anillo de compromiso pero resulta ser un anillo que significa que ella es parte de su l√≠nea. Leila est√° muy perturbada ya que quiere que √©l diga que la ama, cuando no lo har√≠a ella se va y regresa con su amigo vampiro enano en el circo. Alguienpone en marcha una bomba tratando de matarla, pero es salvada por el guardia de la mano derecha de VALD que est√° enamorada de ella. Fingen que est√° muerta para intentar averiguar qui√©n est√° tratando de matarla y VALD pensando que est√° muerta vuela para conseguir sus restos y se dio cuenta de que no son sus restos. Ella se conecta con √©l mientras est√° en un sue√±o y √©l viene a buscarla. Las cosas se ponen muy √°spero con todos los giros y emociones, pero es fant√°stico. Una gran historia y estoy esperando el pr√≥ximo libro. Por favor, date prisa.

2.5 * pero vot√≥ tres aqu√≠ porque todav√≠a me encanta esta escritura autores.Me encanta Kat y Huesos en los autores de la serie Night Huntress, y me encant√≥ Vlad y todo lo que es entonces y ahora, porque nunca cambia. A pesar de que es un personaje consistente, la protagonista femenina, Leila, refleja a Kat de muchas maneras, y por alguna raz√≥n no mide demasiado bien. A todo el mundo le gusta una hero√≠na patada culo, seguro, pero no es lo mismo que el que ya han le√≠do.Para m√≠, esta serie parece una versi√≥n m√°s ligera de Kat y Bones con el contenido sexual atenuado al m√≠nimo en comparaci√≥n con su otra serie, pero a√∫n as√≠ establecido en el mismo mundo que el autor ha creado. Para m√≠, el contenido sexual en estos libros s√≥lo a√±ade otra dimensi√≥n a sus personalidades y c√≥mo reaccionar√≠an en un ambiente crudo o el tipo de pensamientos que tienen en esos momentos desnudos. No estoy seguro de por qu√© el autor hizo un 180 en estas escenas... en mi opini√≥n fue un error.Todav√≠a seguir√© a este autor.

Yo no estaba tan interesado en el uno fuera de Spade y Mencheres, libros ok y disfrut√© de ellos, pero como uno fuera y no lo suficiente para sostener un sereis pero Vlad - bueno √©l es un hombre tan fuerte y detallado que necesita sus propias aventuras. Esto me recuerda mucho el comienzo de la serie cazadora de la noche, donde el d√∫o se unen bastante r√°pidamente. claramente esta serie siendo planeada como un libro de tres cosas se aceleran - personalmente creo que la pareja tiene suficiente personalidad para hacer m√°s de tres libros, y podr√≠a divergir f√°cilmente en una diferente una vez que esta atada. Me encanta la qu√≠mica entre ellos y que Leila no es una chica ¬´s√≠¬ª - se enfrenta a lo que cree en. Cuando se juntan las escenas son Calientes - pero necesitamos m√°s de ellos por favor! Me encanta la aventura y la acci√≥n, pero quiero m√°s del romance tambi√©n...Vlad es uno de mis personajes favoritos, muy complejo y, a veces, un gran sentido del humor. Siempre me ha gustado el antagonismo entre √©l y Bones, aunque vemos poco de eso aqu√≠. Me ha encantado Night Huntress, pero el √∫ltimo par de historias se han sentido un poco rancio, as√≠ que a trav√©s de Vald y Leila siento que hay la oportunidad de reagrupar a la vieja pandilla en algunas historias frescas pero con V y L como estrellas principales. Si est√°s leyendo esta Jeanine, por favor dale un poco, aunque - son demasiado buenos s√≥lo para languidecer en un trato de tres libros, necesitan m√°s y tienen mucho m√°s que hacer estoy seguro!Me encant√≥ el libro en general, buena longitud para realmente entrar en los stpries y m√∫ltiples parcelas. Siento que Maximus tambi√©n tiene m√°s que decir/hacer - √©l ha estado con Vlad por tanto tiempo. Han hecho y visto tanto que debe haber algunas emociones complejas y lazos entre ellos. Marty - √©l es un tipo divertido y desrves m√°s, y por supuesto la familia de Leila, pap√° y hermanita son gente fuerte.esperamos el libro tres - es una l√°stima que tardan tanto en llegar a nosotros aunque, por supuesto, escribir buenas historias no es algo que se pueda apresurar.

Jeaniene Frost est√° en mi lista de autores. Dicho esto, me decepcion√≥ Once Burned. Vlad era tan diferente de los fragmentos que hab√≠amos visto en la serie Cat and Bones. Mostr√≥ a Leila muy poco de la ternura que hab√≠a mostrado a Kira o Cat. Como el √∫ltimo libro de J.R. Ward sali√≥ el mismo d√≠a que casi lo compr√© en lugar de comprar esto. Tan contento que me mantuve leal y compr√© Twice Tempted. Lo le√≠ de una vez y desde entonces lo he le√≠do dos veces m√°s. Casi ten√≠a un rabieta cuando termin√≥. No es exactamente una percha de acantilado final, estaba bien se√±alizado, pero cuando el libro termin√≥ sin resoluci√≥n me sorprendi√≥. Estoy deseando que el tercer libro, cuando sea posible, pero no estoy seguro de cu√°nto m√°s lejos el autor puede llevar la historia de Vlad y Leila. Tal vez ella podr√≠a hacer de Vlad y Leila una versi√≥n europea de Gato y Huesos persiguiendo grandes chicos alrededor de las capitales de Europa.Aunque disfrut√© de este libro que se encuentra detr√°s de Noche Huntress y Noche Huntress World novelas de ah√≠ las 4 estrellas.
Un libro super recomendable, tienes que leerlo, recuerda ¬°visita las librer√≠as locales!

Por mucho que disfrut√© este libro, finalmente llegar a escuchar la historia de Acheron, en realidad me sent√≠ un poco enga√±ado al final.: (Me gust√≥ la primera parte, s√≠ que consigui√≥ un poco mucho y la tortura, etc. se arrastr√≥, pero creo que el tipo de vida que Acheron experiment√≥ fue perfectamente cre√≠ble. ¬øQuer√≠a leer hasta el √∫ltimo y horrible detalle? No. Sin embargo, estaba interesado en escuchar c√≥mo conoci√≥ a Artemis (ella era probablemente el mejor personaje, creo que incluso me gustaba m√°s que Tory. Pero llegaremos a esa en un minuto). Artemisa es un poco cobarde, para ser la Diosa de la Caza, pero al menos ten√≠a algunos lados diferentes para ella. Acheron no era su yo fuerte habitual, pero entonces tal vez lo que vemos de √©l en los otros libros es un frente, √©l es su l√≠der y siempre tiene que encontrarse como uno. Todo el asunto de los Dioses y los diferentes panteones (no creo que lo deletre√© bien) se ponen un poco confusos y realmente no se explican muy bien.La segunda parte volvi√≥ a lo habitual, y lo disfrut√© pero lo √∫nico que realmente me molest√≥ fue Tory. A otras personas les ha gustado, es una cuesti√≥n de opini√≥n, pero pens√© que era una decepci√≥n en comparaci√≥n con un personaje complicado como Acheron. Para ser honesto, prefiero tener a Artemisa, que es decir algo con ella siendo una vaca completa y todo eso. Tory era completamente ordinario, bla, bla, estoy seguro de que ha conocido a miles de ella en su larga vida y honestamente no pod√≠a ver lo especial que era. En todo, creo que el autor podr√≠a haber pasado un poco m√°s de tiempo en la carnada de este libro en algunos lugares.Sin embargo, fue una buena lectura y agradable, hay algunos otros personajes introducidos que ser√°n divertidos de leer. Probablemente sigue siendo una de sus mejores contribuciones a la serie:) Vale la pena leer!

My initial reaction to reading this book: Wow!So we've had constant hints and sneak peaks into Acheron's past but nothing and I do mean nothing prepared me for the real story. First of all, the first half of the book (60% in fact) is taken up by Acheron's past and what a past it is. Not for the faint of heart and certainly not cheerful. If you are expecting the usual kicks and giggles you'll be sorely disappointed at first. Acheron's past is dark, harsh and unrelenting. There are some very heart wrenching moments and although I've never been a fan of Artemis and her treatment of Acheron, knowing the history behind is makes me utterly hate her.After the background story we come back to present times and we find ourselves meeting a character we've met before - Tory. A side character in one of the dream-hunter novels, Tory is now a full grown woman and is causing Acheron more than a little strife with her determination to prove Atlantis was real. For all the harshness of Acheron's history, this part of the book really lightens things, there is humour, affection and, as we've all come to expect, a happy ending. Have to say I had many a heart flutter during the second half of the book. With the knowledge of Acheron's past it would take a truly hard hearted person not to wish happiness of the man. It also, of course, goes to explaining a lot of small things I had not even previously noticed.Excellent book, absolutely addictive, I could hardly put it down and wouldn't have had I not had a toddler to worry about. My only regret is that now that I know Acheron's past some of the mystery that helped keep me addicted is gone. But then again I've yet to meet a Kenyon novel I've not enjoyed, so my regret is a small one. I'd recommend this to anyone and everyone reading the series.

One word - Amazing. This is the book that I have been waiting for in this series if I could give it more than 5 stars then I would. The book is huge and it has taken me about a week to read but I thoroughly enjoyed it from cover to cover. I would 100 percent recommend this book but you may be best reading it in the order of the series rather than as a standalone.This is the fifteenth book in the series and finally we get to hear Acheron the leader of the Dark Hunter's story. The first part of the book is all about Acheron's human life growing up and the abuse he suffered and the hands of his Uncle. Outcast from his family because his Father refused to acknowledge Acheron as his son his story is absolutely heart wrenching and it makes me like him even more as even though he suffered absolute degradation, abuse and hardship whilst living as a human he never takes that out on anyone else when he finally becomes the God he is. The second part of the book is about Acheron now in modern day times and how he meets and falls in love with Soteria (Tory) Kafieri but their love and relationship has one major hurdle to overcome in the form of a red headed Greek Goddess Artemis.It took me quite a while to get around to discovering this series as when you look up Sherrilyn Kenyon on Amazon and these books in list order it actually shows Dragonswan as being the first book (but it's not) and Dragonswan is never ever available to buy! As a girl who likes to read all books in a series and most definitely the first one in a series, thinking that I couldn't get the first book did actually stop me starting the series. I have only just discovered that the first book is actually Fantasy Lover, read this and have now proceeded to order the rest of the series:) Sherrilyn has now joined the ranks on Gena Showalter and Kresley Cole on my favourite authors list.

Its ben a long time coming for all the original Dark Hunter fans but finally Ash's book is here. It doesn't disappoint.The first half of the book is about Acheron's past, told mainly through the eyes of his sister Ryssa. Ryssa is the only member of his family who really cares about him and this is a nice relief from the constant abuse that he suffers. The first half of the book is all about making sense of all the family rivalries, loyalties, Gods and Godesses. Its a mammoth section of the book and quite rightly as everything that has been hinted at in previous novels now begins to make sense - Ash's relationship with Artemis, Apollymi, Simi, Styxx and Apollo.The second half of the book brings us right back up to speed in New Orleans after hurricane Katrina and with it introduces the anthropologist Torey who thinks she has discovered Atlantis. The fact that she has also discovered Ryssa's diary leads her to Ash. She is the geeky, clumsy, gutsy and intelligent heroine that Ash deserves. This is the Ash that we know and love, but I have to admit that although he makes perfect sense after reading the first half of the book he doesn't always tally with the Ash of previous novels. The Zen master Ash who always had a witty comeback and an all-seeing presence is replaced by a more human Ash (weirdly for an Atlantean God).However minor grumble aside, this is a great book, I really don't believe that anyone who has been reading the series (and please don't try and start with this one if you haven't) will be let down by this. There are some brilliant scenes in the book in particular when Artmeis gets her ass kicked but also when all the ex-Dark Hunters appear.It may not be the last book in the series but it does feel like the end of an era. So a triumphant farewell and bring on the next phase of the Dark Hunters. I can't wait!

I have waited for so long for this book, I just snapped it up when it came out - although I had to wait for some time before starting it because I wanted to 'take my time'. I've always loved Ash's character in the DH books and we got hints of his life throughout the Dark Hunter series - especially in Zarek's book, where Ash lets Zarek 'see' his a part of his past where he too was treated badly by his father.I absolutely adored it! It's over 700 pages long and, from the very first page, we're riveted. I resented having to put it down - even to sleep! Drove my husband crazy - oops...!Having read a most of Sherilyn's 'DH' books, all JR's 'Black Dagger' books, and all Christine's 'Dark' series, I have to say that 'Acheron' tops the lot. To me, his is THE ultimate hero. Loved him. Loved Ryssa, Simi (always) Tory and her friends. Loved Appollymi (that surprised me!). Couldn't stand Artie (no surprise there), Styxx (until later) and all the other bad guys in his 'family'. I laughed, I (actually) cried, I felt elated, I felt real terror in places. I just loved the book. SK takes this well-loved character, and the series, to a stratispheric level. Unlike some other series I've read recently, this one definitely didn't disappoint me.But don't take my word for it, readers - or the word of the other 19 5 star reviewers... JUST BUY IT!

The first part of this book is cookbook sad my poor heart couldn't take it,but I read on because I was hoping that ask fines love and happiness because he deserves it,well while that did happen I wanted more at the end I wanted babies and even though he ends up happy for some reason I just think the ending was not satisfying enough for me .but I'm happy for my characters and I hope Nick fines happiness.

Kenyon simply blew me away with her latest dark hunter book. it has been one of the most anticipated books to date for me and she followed through beautifully.At first when I read some of the reviews and realised that the story only picked up in modern times after about 400 pages I was disappointed but i am not anymore. The back story and full disclosure of what Ash has suffered through really got me, emotionally and physically - crying and everything! It also got me to look at him in a totally different way. I am now tempted to go back and read through all of the earlier books just for the glimpse of Ash and see new subtext to his actions and words - like his hatred of anyone at his back. it is explained clearly in this book. I also really hate Artemis now. I forgave her a bit in Katra's book but now I spit on her :)After getting through all of the heavy emotional past story - you'll need tissues - the modern story is every bit as wonderful. I love the ending. I couldn't see how they could end up together but was determined that they would lol. Tory is a great character and meshes well with Ash. I missed them when I turned the last page - evidence of great writing.READ IT...you certainly will not regret it.

I LOVED this book, I swear I resented every second I had to put it down and do something else!I loved the different styles of writing (1st and 3rd person) and it was all very fast-paced while being emotive. I did perhaps get a bit frustrated in the first half of the book simply because what happens to Acheron is so horrible and I felt it didn't need hammering home quite so much. Then again, it does make you really start to hate Artemis, so I can see the point of it.The second half was a brilliant contrast to the first - lighter and sometimes laugh-out-loud funny. You still hate Artemis, and you develop a great respect for Ash simply because, despite the provocation to act differently, he's always true to himself.I was gripped by this book, a very very good read, so don't be put off by the size of it. It looks hefty but it's worth it! And now I can't wait for Artemis to get seriously slapped down. Bring it on, Sherrilyn!

I love the Dark Hunter series and Acheron was always my favourite character but when I read this book I fell for him all over again. It explains his idiosyncrasies and reasons behind his actions so well and believably. The book is very sad at the beginning and graphic but not gratuitously so. Child abuse is rarely covered in romantic fiction but it fits here and makes you ache with the awfulness and unfairness of the situation Ash finds himself in. I think it also reinforces the horror that is the abuse of our most vulnerable and the scars it leaves for the rest of their lives. This book is just wonderful.
El libro es maravilloso, tan real y lleno de sentimientos sin perder es toque de humor. Los personajes tienen una relaci√≥n muy bonita que me ten√≠a emocionada con cada p√°gina. Muy recomendado!!

***Audio Review ***üåüüåüüåüüåüüåü Lo que un 'veh√≠culo' absolutamente perfecto fue esta historia para mostrar el maravilloso talento vocal de Joe Jameson. Los acentos sorprendentes, una voz distinta para cada personaje... incluyendo los femeninos, e incluso logr√≥ conseguir algunas sensaciones all√≠ en alg√∫n lugar tambi√©n üòâ; de hecho, varias de sus narraciones est√°n en mi estanter√≠a 'Awesome Audio Narration' aqu√≠ en Goodreads. Me parece recordar leer en alguna parte que Alexis estaba bastante impresionado con la narraci√≥n de Joe para el cl√°sico de Mary Renault, The Charioteer... como yo üòä, as√≠ que estoy pensando que tal vez es por eso que Joe fue elegido para narrar este? Tambi√©n s√© que Joe narra como Hamish Long y Rusty Coles para varias de las historias de Harper Fox... en particular Brothers of the Wild North Sea, que fue fabuloso. 5 estrellas definitivamente para la narraci√≥n.En lo que respecta a la historia de no sexo en la p√°gina y a los personajes, me temo que no era mi favorito de las historias de Aleis [que el honor sigue siendo compartido por For Real y Glitterland]. Aunque fue bl**dy gracioso... re√≠rse en voz alta graciosa a veces, especialmente el gormless Alex Twaddle y su show de 'Hooray Henry', y Rhys Jones Bowen siendo el gur√∫ de TI gal√©s m√°s inepto que podr√≠as desear conocer. S√≠, puedes hacer una excepci√≥n a algunas partes de la historia, pero oye, es FICCI√ìN... se permite una peque√±a licencia art√≠stica. Me encant√≥ el drippy Bridget que ten√≠a un acento perfecto 'Sloane Ranger', y la madre de Luc con su muy relajado inconveniente franc√©s tambi√©n era buena. Todo el mundo [bueno, aparte del jefe de Luc en CRAPP üòâ] fue tan amable y servicial; en realidad era Luc con quien tuve problemas. Simplemente no me conect√© completamente con [o como] √©l hasta bastante tarde en la historia, aunque me encant√≥ Oliver la mayor parte del tiempo... hasta que sus papeles fueron tristemente invertidos hacia el final de la historia, y yo estaba tan molesto üò°. Alexis y sus observaciones de car√°cter son, como de costumbre, el lugar en su mayor parte. Cuanto menos se diga sobre el donante de esperma in√∫til de Luc y los padres controladores y desagradables de Oliver, para quienes nada de lo que sus hijos adultos hicieron nunca fue agradable o lo suficientemente bueno, mejor. Me sorprendi√≥ bastante que el HfN terminara justo al final de la historia, debo decir [fue como un equipo de f√∫tbol consiguiendo un igualador muy tarde en una final de Copa para llevar el partido a tiempo extra, despu√©s de que la oposici√≥n pensara que ya hab√≠an cosido el partido]. Por supuesto, aunque el autor [ES] es casi tan por excelencia ingl√©s/brit√°nico como se puede obtener, tenemos un editor estadounidense üòè as√≠ que siempre tenemos algunos americanismos lanzados en la historia tambi√©n, que obviamente no funcionan aqu√≠ tambi√©n, por ejemplo, gradas, delitos graves, alma mater y fuego de basurero. Tenemos que aceptar que no quedan demasiados editores LGBTQ+ aqu√≠ en el Reino Unido para que autores realmente buenos [y Alexis es definitivamente un muy buen autor] transfieran las ventas para ganarse la vida aceptable, as√≠ que lamentablemente los editores estadounidenses son un 'mal' necesario, me temo.Con todo, estoy muy contento de haber comprado tambi√©n el audio de esta historia. Fue deliciosa!! 4.5 estrellas redondeadas para la historia.

Calling it now, this will be on the best of 2020 reads. Such an absolutely brilliant read and so well written.When an author creates their own words and those words are perfect nouns or verbs or just about anything, then that author needs to have all the plaudits. To rocher, will forever now be the verb for creating a pyramid of golden chocolates and offering them to your guests.The whole book is like Notting Hill, meets Friends mixed with Four Weddings and a Funeral and a Harry Enfield sketch.The characters from friends to work mates are just brilliant. Dead funny. Alex really is Tim Nice But Dim. The joke of the day routine made me roll on the floor laughing. Bridget with her ridiculously funny accidents. The James Royce Royces. I‚Äôm laughing thinking about it. The Dick pics. The dung beetles. This is a book that is meant to be funny and it is.But Luc and Oliver, I just adore them. I‚Äôm smitten. I want to buy hedgehog boxers for the hubster. I want to hug the pair of them (and also clean Luc‚Äôs flat). I want to tell Jon Fleming to jog right off and tell Odile O‚ÄôDonnell that she‚Äôs mumtastic (I made up that word).5 stars. All the stars.

Right from the start of this story, Lucien, the main character and narrator, makes a very poor impression. He is needy but hateful, distrustful but desperate to be loved, his is unpleasant to everyone and the upset when they treat him poorly in return. He is a nasty piece of work, but since he is the narrator, we only have is word for that.And Luc's life is more complicated than most. The child of two estranged 80's rock stars, he has never met his famous father. His father's career is re-awakened by a reality TV show and suddenly the press want to know all about Luc. When you have no money, talent or anything good in you life, having a paparazzi photographer on hand to capture your every slip up is no fun at all.When the negative attention puts Luc's job on the line, he knows he has to clean up his act. The plan? a fake relationship, with a fake boyfriend, who ticks all the 'respectable gay' boxes and can, perhaps, make him seem a little more acceptable.Oliver is perfect, just a bit too perfect perhaps. He is good looking, polite, well dressed, generous, kind, has a very respectable job and a reason to need a fake boyfriend too.Of course Luc will mess up, there is only so much even a fake boyfriend as understanding and Oliver can handle in a fake relationship. And when what should be fake starts feeling real, things are bound to get complicated.I am going to be honest - I almost gave up reading after the first few chapters, Luc was such a P in the A, and his constant needily self deprecating jokes really annoyed me, and Oliver was too too perfect in every way, really, what was he doing? But of course Luc is the narrator, and he hates himself, and so we hate him too, and he sees Oliver as the perfect example of the virtues he does not possess, he cannot see the flaws. As the book progresses the author is able to pull us back from this and both characters become more real and rounded, and even, perhaps, likeable. It is quite a feat.This book is a slow developer - the usual romance formula (where it all kick off at exactly 33%) goes right out the window, and it is so much the better for it.This is an entertaining read, there are a lot of very clever jokes in here, and a good number of then are actually funny.I liked this book. I ended it really caring about Luc and Olivier, and bizarrely, dung beetles.

Luc O‚ÄôDonnell, a 28-year-old son of 1980s rockstars, has a bit of a reputation. So when he‚Äôs photographed, face down in the street complete with Anne Summers bunny ears, after leaving in a party, the headlines are rather scathing. So much so, he is at risk of losing his job unless he can rescue his reputation. The suggestion is he finds a suitable boyfriend and that he endeavours to rehabilitate his reputation. Become a good gay in the eyes of others The candidate is criminal barrister Oliver Blackwood ‚Äì handsome, conservative but, from their previous meetings, not impressed with Luc...Alexis Hall‚Äôs prose is sarcastic, irrelevant and yet perspicacious. Boyfriend Material takes several Rom-Com clich√©s ‚Äì talking through doors, doorstep reconciliations, the arrangement that gets emotionally messy - and employs then in a mocking manner that is both amusing but, on another level, also addresses several issues within the portrayal of queer relationships.It‚Äôs very different in style and tone in Glitterland or the Billionaire trilogy. Throughout I found myself smiling and laughing. Recommended

I picked this book up because I'd seen so many people talking about it. Plus, I love the cover.Luc needs a very respectable fake boyfriend. Oliver wants someone to accompany him to his parent's ruby wedding anniversary. It seems like a sensible arrangement for both of them.I loved Luc's voice. It was funny and relatable. I thought Oliver, the perfect man with host of insecurities, was adorable. Some of the secondary characters were hilarious (Luc really dislikes Oxford grads!). The scene with Oliver's friends was wonderful.I really enjoyed this book. It was laugh out loud funny and incredibly touching in turns.

When you wake your other half up laughing at a book you know it's a great book!! I wasn't sure what to expect as I read a different series from Alexis Hall which was much darker. I thought this book was so sweet, the two main characters very well developed and even when they were being plonkers there was still something really endearing about them (went off Oliver for a bit round the end of chapter 52 but he redeemed himself!). It was also very funny, the supporting characters were fab and honestly laughed like a drain for about five minutes straight over the badgers. Well worth a recommendation, have a feeling I'll read it again a lot.

Witty and punny, I loved the humour, then the author catches you right in the feels when you‚Äôre not paying attention! The people comparing it to Four Weddings/Notting Hill - I agree! But with far more diversity than Curtis ever managed. 5 stars and it left me starry-eyed.

Couldn‚Äôt put this down, this was a fantastic read, and I‚Äôm so grateful it was recommended to me. Luc and Oliver are wonderful, charming, flawed, scared, and brilliant together. I emoted all over the place. A book this good doesn‚Äôt need my positive review but I definitely wanted to express my appreciation. If you read this you won‚Äôt regret it.

This book was completely hilarious - Alex & Miffy alone had me in sitches! The story was also really touching in parts and felt really grounded and real in a way that drew you in, endeared you to these characters and made Luc especially relatable in many ways. It was a page turner for sure and I thoroughly enjoyed it!

Anna Karenina, una dama rusa que se mueve en c√≠rculos de √©lite, se embarca en un camino autodestructivo despu√©s de su encuentro con el gregario conde Vronsky. Ubicada en Rusia en el siglo XIX, Tolstoi representa un relato detallado de los personajes y del mundo en el que se mueven. El lento declive de Anna en la sociedad se refleja en el √©xito gradual de Levin en la vida.

I have to confess that time travel is one of my weaknesses. I just love the imaginative feelings this type of book or film gives me. 'Somewhere in Time' definitely is one of my favourites, both book and film. Ahhh! Back to business though... I did enjoy this book and after a slightly slow start it fascinated me. I don't like spoilers in reviews so will not give in to the temptation to reveal too many details. Sufficient to say the illness that is part of the plot might depress some readers. It is however for me a beautiful novel. It deals with time travel and romance with one human being searching for love. The longing to be with someone you love deeply and the heartache that can be incurred on the journey is central to the story and is accepted by the main character as unavoidable in his journey towards his dream. It is often said that true love overcomes all obstacles to eventually triumph. That belief is quite complex though in real life. It certainly does not mean that everyone achieves the goal of being together with the one who is loved - enough said. If you are romantic at heart however and enjoy time travel books don't miss this utterly poignant but delightful story, both film and book version.

Lovely book. I like many saw & fell in love with the film first. I love both book & film equally. The 1st 20 pages are the only problem with the book as they do not flow well, once past them - I was hooked. Richard matheson wrote both the book AND film and it is interesting to see how he changed the original story slightly for the film. The book like the film conveys completely the feeling that Richard collier felt utterly compelled to go back in time & meet elise, & the sweet gentle loving character of richard is plain to see - & having read facts about the film - this was why Christopher reeve was chosen to play Richard. As in the film - beautiful music plays a key part - in the book it is mahler, in the film it is rhapsody on a theme by paganini. The writer draws you into Richards plight so well & the time travel aspect is fascinating. The writer's love for the genteel late victoriana era and poignant classisal music is a key element. What is so poignant - is that both Richard & elise love each other deeply - although they have not been together long, yet they are denied their happiness ultimately. A beautiful,touching story - that will always have a place in my heart

After seeing the film several times over the years, I decided to purchase and to read the book version. It's good to have the book as well as seeing the film as you can compare the two which are excellent in their own right (some prefer the film, some prefer the book, some like the two equally, everyone's different).A little spoiler:It's a heartbreaking but lovely story of: time travel, love, romance, never giving up on wanting to be with the one you love; your soulmate, and desiring to be with them come what may. Without giving the plot and storyline away too much so as not to spoil it for others, what I will say is that if you want to read a book that gives you a glimpse into just how far people are prepared to go to be with another person - despite going through anguish and despair to get there - it will move your heart and soul, this story, and you'll come away feeling that love truly does triumph over any obstacle put in its path.The book was packaged very well, arrived before the 'due date' and there's nothing nicer than opening the packaging and holding a brand-new book in your hands, written by a gifted and wonderful author - Richard Matheson, who takes you on a wonderful heartwarming emotional journey with you not being able to put the book down, it's that good.I highly-recommend Somewhere in Time to any reader who enjoys romantic time-travel stories, with drama and suspense included too.

Actually, my rating for this book is 3.9 stars. It does take a LONG time to get going (the first 100+ pages are actually verging on boring), but once it does, it will not let you go. I agree with one of the other reviewers, the ending is rushed - it seems like Richard Matheson suddenly realised that he had to end the story somehow. Oddly enough, the movie's ending, which is pretty much the same, does not feel rushed at all. Weird.Also, (again, I'm agreeing with another reviewer), I don't see why Richard had to be dying from a brain tumor. It did nothing whatsoever for the story (except at the very end, when it was used to potentially explain everything that happened in the story).Anyway, the story is great, really great, but I can't give it 5 stars because it takes so long to get going. I would recommend it, definitely

Someone recommended this as one of the most romantic stories of all time, so I had to have a look!I loved it, a book about time travel AND romance all in one great!The book starts with Richard Colliers' brother telling us that he has come across notes of his brothers and is having them printed, he doesn't think they are true (who would?) but Richard believed it and here is the story. Richard is dying from a brain tumor, he can't stand seeing the look of pity and pain in his brothers face, so decides to take off and go somewhere to die by himself. He stops along the way at an old Victorian hotel, enjoys the genteel feel of the place so stays for a day or two. Whilst there he sees a photograph of an actress, Elise McKenna, who had performed at the hotel on 20th November 1896. He falls in love with the photo of Elise and simply can't get her out of his mind. He does a lot of research on her and is intrigued by the story of her performance that night and the fact that there was a guest of the hotel who attended the performance called R C Collier! He fantasises about meeting Elise and is so convinced that if he can THINK hard enough about that night he will be able to go back to 20th November 1896! as this date happens to be a few days ahead (in his own time of 1971) he makes his plans.He does go back of course and meets his soulmate Elise McKenna. Unfortunately things do not work out for the lovers although you are willing it so much for them! and after an eventful 2 days Richard is flung back to his own time ,1971.You get so caught up in the story and are so disappointed when things go awry for them, although you know from the beginning of the story that it can not work out.A lovely little book, a lovely story and really you should give it a go! If you enjoy time travel and romance.Reminds me strongly of Jack Finney's "Time and Again" another very good read!

I would never have read this book if it was not for a review on Paul Magrs' blog. I was enchanted by the story and the different questions it raised in me as a reader. The story is well constructed and poignant and much better I think than the film, which I watched the next day. I felt the story slowed just a little in the middle, but I loved it all the same. It felt quite profound to be reading it so soon after the death of Richard Matheson as I read that this was in his opinion one of the best books he had written. I look forward to reading more from this author.

En "Luz de Abril" volvemos a sentir la luz inconfundible de Clara Fuertes: la mujer, el amor, viajar. En las historias de Clara Fuertes hay siempre amor, mucho, y de diferentes tipos: amor por uno mismo y la necesidad de curarse el coraz√≥n, como le ocurre a Abril; amor valiente por lo prohibido, en este caso, el prohibido Sanjay de Mar√≠a; y el amor por los paisajes y el arte de las cosas, que es al final lo que marca sobre todo la narrativa de esta autora.Efectiva evocaci√≥n de La India: "...Y ma√±ana a Delhi."

La Madre Tierra pertenece a su verdadera gente. [‚Ä¶] ‚ÄìEso es lo que cre√©is vosotros. Pero seg√∫n nuestro pueblo, la tierra puede comprarse. [‚Ä¶] Nadie quiere rob√°rosla. Ellos s√≥lo est√°n cogiendo lo que el gobierno les da o aquello por lo que pagaron. [‚Ä¶] Nosotros somos m√°s fuertes. Tenemos mejores armas. Cuando os ve√°is superados en n√∫mero y rodeados, deber√©is abandonar vuestras creencias y aceptar las nuevas. [‚Ä¶] ‚ÄìTu coraz√≥n grita no. Nuestros corazones gritan no. La fuerza no es siempre buena, Ojos Azules. No pidas a esta comanche que haga lo que t√∫ no puedes. Es sabio.¬ªA pesar de sus diferencias, Loretta y Cazador, poco a poco, se van encontrando a s√≠ mismos, vi√©ndose obligados a afrontar un odio en el que se hab√≠an refugiado desde hac√≠a mucho tiempo. En l√≠neas generales, creo que el desarrollo de ambos es muy bueno y complejo. Loretta debe superar un pasado que, a medida que lo vamos descubriendo, m√°s dif√≠cil de perdonar nos parece; y Cazador debe dejar afrontar un pasado y un futuro que lo llevan hacia un camino que no est√° seguro de poder recorrer. La forma en la que afrontan sus circunstancias de m√°s de un giro que, en determinados momentos da densidad al desenlace, pero Anderson tiene una narrativa pulida y un ritmo que logran que la novela no decaiga.En resumen, creo que es una novela larga, con un romance tierno y algo complejo que se desarrolla en con un tel√≥n de fondo que da que pensar y que te recuerda que realidad est√° llena de matices y que no todo es blanco o negro.¬´Ella y Cazador eran como semillas flotando en el viento. [‚Ä¶] A trav√©s de ellos, los antepasados vivir√≠an.¬ª

He terminado de leer el maravilloso libro de la Bailarina de Auschwitz, que como dice la autora Edith Eger es, m√°s que un libro con una historia real, cruda y en muchos momentos conmovedores, es un instrumento de sanci√≥n. No hay p√°gina donde no haya encontrado una frase o varias que me hayan tocado en lo m√°s profundo o me hayan hecho comprender el dolor, la p√©rdida, los sacrificios, de manera diferente, m√°s humana pues son palabras que surgen, no s√≥lo desde su cabeza y su coraz√≥n, sino desde lo m√°s profundo de su alma, que aprendi√≥ a ver la vida y a darle un diferente significado a partir de haber hecho un largo recorrido para sanar y trascender su dolor y no s√≥lo el de ella, sino el de todos sus pacientes. Muchas, muchas, muchas gracias a Edith Eger por su fuerza y su coraje para compartirnos su historia, sus comprensiones acerca de la vida y su amor hacia los suyos y hacia su misma. Y en eso radica lo bueno que es este relato, es simplemente muy honesto; no busca motivar, no busca vanagloriarse ni mostrar una realidad no existe (a diferencia de otras autobiograf√≠as), √©sta es por mucho la m√°s sincera que he le√≠do. El autor simplemente cuenta su historia sin filtro alguno; lo bueno, lo malo y lo feo de haber fundado y dirigido Nike : La presi√≥n en la que viv√≠a al tener 2 trabajos para poder pagar las cuentas y mantener a flote su compa√±√≠a, la soledad esto le significaba, el alcohol que era su medio de escape y las veces que se quedaba dormido en su coche por la madrugada totalmente intoxicado por tratar de liberar un poco de la presi√≥n lo ahogaba, los apoyos, las traiciones, demandas, su obsesi√≥n con Aiddas, la falta de liquidez que lo hizo ser un hombre endeudado la mayor parte de su vida adulta, la satisfacci√≥n de ver como doblaba el n√∫mero de ventas cada a√±o, pero la frustraci√≥n de caer en cuenta que ni aun as√≠ era tan rentable como pudiera suponerse, esas temidas juntas con los inversores que no se tentaban el coraz√≥n para hablarle duro y tratar de manera despectiva a quien a√±os mas tarde aparecer√≠a en Forbes como una de las personas m√°s ricas del mundo.Te deja ver el lado Humano del empresario millonario, ese icono de la cultura occidental que son percibidos como Dioses; la encarnaci√≥n del sue√±o capitalista, comenzar sin nada y terminar millonario. El autor desmitifica ese constructo para mostrarse como en realidad es: Una persona con virtudes y defectos que supo aprovechar muchas cosas para convertirse en millonario y que cometi√≥ infinidad de errores empresariales y personales, pero que reconoce aun con todo su conocimiento, que no hay ninguna formula para el √©xito, ni siquiera el seguir y seguir peleando.En su narrativa hay un componente m√≠stico del porqu√© le pasan las cosas y al igual que Ford en su autobiograf√≠a, habla de cierto misticismo que le ayudo a crear y mantener su empresa. Creyente de las filosof√≠as orientales, hace una mezcla de todas las que conoce para darle sentido a la vida, iniciando por un viaje donde concibe la idea de fundar una empresa de calzado hasta la construcci√≥n del edificio principal de su empresa, esto es interesante porque lo expresa de una manera muy pragm√°tica, en mi desperto cierta curiosidad hac√≠a estas doctrinas.Es una historia muy resumida, la longitud precisa para no aburrir al lector y atraparlo en el libro; facil de leer, esta escrito para todo el mundo, lo mismo un estudiante de preparatoria o un empresario, estoy seguro que ambos podr√°n disfrutarlo y sacar provecho de √©l. Llega a ser hasta c√≥mico cuando te cuenta sus experiencias, m√°s de una vez me sac√≥ una sonrisa y hasta una carcajada.Contra:Realmente no encuentro alg√∫n defecto en este libro, fue muy de mi agrado, pero si tuviera que mencionar alguna ser√≠a que est√° traducido en Espa√±ol europeo, por lo que algunas frases y conjugaciones pueden leerse raras a ojos de un latinoamericano. Y que la calidad de los materiales del que est√° hecho es muy mala.Frase que define al libro:Me gustar√≠a recordarles que Estados Unidos no es el Shangri-La empresarial que la gente cree. El libre comercio siempre irrita a los troles que viven para bloquear, parar frustrar, para decir ‚Äúno, lo siento, no‚Äù y siempre ha sido as√≠. And also Deadpool.Overall, I'll keep reading. 8/10.

Pros:Es un libro escrito sin pretensi√≥n alguna. Llega a ser hasta c√≥mico cuando te cuenta sus experiencias, m√°s de una vez me sac√≥ una sonrisa y hasta una carcajada.Contra:Realmente no encuentro alg√∫n defecto en este libro, fue muy de mi agrado, pero si tuviera que mencionar alguna ser√≠a que est√° traducido en Espa√±ol europeo, por lo que algunas frases y conjugaciones pueden leerse raras a ojos de un latinoamericano. Y que la calidad de los materiales del que est√° hecho es muy mala.Frase que define al libro:Me gustar√≠a recordarles que Estados Unidos no es el Shangri-La empresarial que la gente cree. El libre comercio siempre irrita a los troles que viven para bloquear, parar frustrar, para decir ‚Äúno, lo siento, no‚Äù y siempre ha sido as√≠. Y si a eso le sumamos el efecto del ‚Äúfiltro de burbuja‚Äù que se genera de forma autom√°tica por los algoritmos para presentarnos una realidad limitada y conformada por nuestros propios deseos y preferencias, cayendo en un c√≠rculo auto contenido de ficci√≥n, que se retroalimente y auto confirma por nosotros mismos.Harari platea que hacia 2048, ‚Äúlas estructuras f√≠sicas y cognitivas tambi√©n se desvanecer√°n en el aire o en una nube de bits de datos‚Äù . Voy a mencionarles lo positivo, negativo y para quien est√° dirigido.Negativo:- Es demasiado coloquial por lo cual si eres de otro pa√≠s hispano que no sea M√©xico probablemente no entiendas algunas expresiones por parte de la autora.- Cuando menciona los tipos de casas de bolsa, no trae una lista de las 10 mejores casas de bolsa de alg√∫n a√±o como del 2013 o algo por el estilo, si bien, esto ayudar√≠a bastante para saber cuales son casas de bolsa fiables y que se puedan adaptar a mis necesidades.- No trae estrategias detalladas de inversi√≥n, dado que las estrategias se adaptan al tipo de inversionista que seas.Positivas:- Es una muy buena introducci√≥n al mundo de las inversiones si no tienes ni idea de que son, como funcionan y como se manejan.- Es bastante claro y llevadero por lo cual es f√°cil de leer y entender, lo cual se agradece mucho cuando se trata de un tema bastante aburrido pero importante- La autora tiene un canal en youtube donde tiene buenos consejos para cada situaci√≥n durante el a√±o en curso.- Tiene ilustraciones y tablas que refuerzan el entendimiento de las explicaciones.- Es divertido, ya que te puede sacar una que otra sonrisa con sus referencias para explicar un concepto.Esta dirigido a:- Personas que ya tienen un ahorro arriba de $10,000 pesos y quieren invertir su dinero y no dejarlo empolvado en una cuenta de ahorros.- Personas que quieran aprender un poco sobre los tipos de inversiones que existen en M√©xico y conceptos sobre inversiones en general.En lo personal lo recomiendo mucho y vale muy bien el precio.

Compre este libro pues empece a investigar sobre como invertir mi dinero que normalmente esta sentado en mi cuenta de nomina.Es incre√≠ble como √©ste libro me ayud√≥ a entender mejor las inversiones, y hacerlas sentir mucho mas f√°cil de lo que normalmente pensamos que son.No he le√≠do el libro original de peque√±o cerdo capitalista, pues no me considero una persona tan mal financieramente: hago presupuestos y ahorro dinero normalmente. Siempre quise invertir y alguna vez fui a un banco a preguntar opciones pero me quede en las mismas. En los bancos no se van a poner a explicarte los detalles de t√©rminos comunes de inversi√≥n y otras cosas.Este libro me ayud√≥ inmensamente a comprender como el dinero que normalmente tengo sentado esta perdiendo cada mes poder adquisitivo, y c√≥mo tenerlo invertido aunque sea en CETES es algo que es mejor que tenerlo ahi.Lo recomiendo ampliamente para cualquier persona que quiere ahorrar. Lo √∫nico "malo" es que las gr√°ficas y datos que sacan son actualizados hasta el 2013. Lo deber√≠an de actualizar nada mas con eso pues en 5 a√±os ya se le pueden agregar mas informaci√≥n a como han cambiado las cosas. Pero quiero aclarar que aunque las gr√°ficas est√©n desactualizadas, la informaci√≥n sigue siendo valida pues no se trata de comprar el libro para saber como va cierto valor, sino saber como invertir, cuando y donde.

Recomendado si buscas aprender temas financieros relacionados con inversiones, tipos, riesgos etc. asi como todos los conceptos b√°sicos alrededor del estos temas. Como libro educativo resulta muy bueno. Les debo una estrellita porque si bien s√© que se escribi√≥ hace algunos a√±os, algunos datos estad√≠sticos y gr√°ficas est√°n algo atrasados y en ocasiones dan la impresi√≥n de no estar viendo la informaci√≥n m√°s actual y se entiende pues resulta complicado estar actualizando a√±o con a√±o un libro. Pero dicho eso, los temas que se tratan y las reglas que se siguen no cambia pr√°cticamente nada adem√°s de que estan explicados de tal forma que el entenderlos resulta muy sencillo y a veces hasta obvio!.Ayudemos a fomentar la educaci√≥n financiera en nuestro pa√≠s y l√©an!

La m√°s reciente novela de Arriaga es una aut√©ntica tragedia. Una muestra palpable de la enorme falta de creatividad que sacude a este pa√≠s con la misma violencia que las balas que nos zumban los o√≠dos. Otra historia destinada a convertirse en una m√°s de las 20,000 series, pel√≠culas y novelas de narcos, delitos y da√±os colaterales que pretenden definir a una generaci√≥n.La trama es tan altamente improbable que resulta imposible. Desde mi punto de vista no.Para empeorar las cosas la novela ha sido galardonada con el Premio Alfaguara. Me deja sin aliento que un texto rancio que hemos le√≠do en varios lugares sea la bandera con la que se busca mantener la fe en la literatura hispanoamericana. No pierdo la esperanza de que seguiremos encontrando historias cuyos personajes y calidad narrativa nos vuelvan a emocionar en el futuro. De esas repletas de frases mordaces que calen hondo. Para mi no hay otro camino que marcar una sana distancia con las obras receptoras de este premio. Es evidente que cada vez margina m√°s el m√©rito literario y privilegia las razones comerciales.
No entiendes porqu√© gan√≥ un premio..Vulgar, con contenidos pseudo intelectuales.No lo resist√≠.. No pude avanzar mas all√° del 15 por ciento.Hay libros de 15 pesos mas valiosos que √©ste.

Here's the thing. I have been struggling with depression and anxiety for the bettter part of the last 6 years. As you may well know by this, my life now, despite myself being a bit better, is a total chaos. My house is chaos (and I live alone), my routines are chaos (and include 10+ hours of surfing the web), my relationships are chaos (and so many people have chosen to stay away) and it all created a weird unending cycle because a living environment that is a complete chaos can actually make you depressed and anxious, but being anxious and depressed will put your living environment in a complete chaos.Not anymore.Or rather, it's starting to actually change. One small change at a time. Using this well explained and well researched little book I was able to put some order into all of the chaos. It's not a huge change right now, at least not from the outside, but being able to breath more calmly because at the very least I can keep some order and do some light cleaning around my life it's a huge deal for someone that has the problems I do. Everyday now I wake up at the same time, I do some light cleaning, cook something healthier and do five minutes of breathing afterwards. Enough to keep me more focused and less prone to sudden mood changes if things don't go great during the rest of the day. And I know this is just the start.This is the book to change your life. If you are desperate enough to change it and honest enough to recognize you need some extra help (besides medicine and therapy, which also help a lot! by the way, but sometimes we need a little extra).And I just can't recommend it enough to anyone that is looking to do something else, to get themselves out of a tough emotional situation or that just want a better overall life for themselves and those around them.

He terminado de leer el maravilloso libro de la Bailarina de Auschwitz, que como dice la autora Edith Eger es, m√°s que un libro con una historia real, cruda y en muchos momentos conmovedores, es un instrumento de sanci√≥n. No hay p√°gina donde no haya encontrado una frase o varias que me hayan tocado en lo m√°s profundo o me hayan hecho comprender el dolor, la p√©rdida, los sacrificios, de manera diferente, m√°s humana pues son palabras que surgen, no s√≥lo desde su cabeza y su coraz√≥n, sino desde lo m√°s profundo de su alma, que aprendi√≥ a ver la vida y a darle un diferente significado a partir de haber hecho un largo recorrido para sanar y trascender su dolor y no s√≥lo el de ella, sino el de todos sus pacientes. Muchas, muchas, muchas gracias a Edith Eger por su fuerza y su coraje para compartirnos su historia, sus comprensiones acerca de la vida y su amor hacia los suyos y hacia su misma.
